editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE BOKE FOR A Iuſtyce of Peace neuer ſo well and dylygently ſet forthe.

div.head: To the reader.
div.p:
THys boke of Iuſtyce of peace is amended nowe at this impryntyng as in the allegacyon of the yeres of ſtatutes, & the chapters of the ſame. And furthermore many ſtatutes, that in dyuers caſes charge the layd Iuſtycers of Peace, be added to: yt were neuer before prynted in the ſayd boke, one cauſe is for many of them haue ben enacted, ſyth the tyme that the ſame boke was fyrſt compyled, whiche was a very good acte. For lyghtly there is nothynge belongynge to a Iuſtyce of the Peace to do, as concernynge the proceſſe of theyr ſeſſyōs, to make warrantes, Superſedias, Enditemētes of hyghe Treaſon, pety treaſon, felonies appe •
les, treſpaſſes vpon ſtatutes and contra regis pacem, but it is conteyned in this lycle boke.

div.head: Iuſtyce of peace
¶ What men ſhulde be Iuſtyces of the peace theyr auctoryte and power, the forme of theyr charges, and wherof they may enquire, drawen out of the Statutes and the commen lawes.
div.p: IN euery coūtye good mē and lawfull, yt be no maynteyners of euyll, nor barretours in the countreye, ſhalbe aſſingned to be Iuſtyces of ye peace The Statute therof is. Anno primo Edwardi tertii ſtatuto ſecūdo Capitulo decimoſexto.

¶ Good men and lawefull ſhalbe aſſygned in euery ſhyre to kepe the peace, and at the tyme of the aſſygnementes mencyon ſhall be made, that ſuche as ſhall be endyted, or taken by the ſayde kepers of the Peace, ſhall nat be lette to maynpryſe by the ſhyryffes, nor by none other mynyſtres, yf they be nat maynpernable by the lawe. Anno quarto Edwardi tertii Capitulo ſecundo.

¶ Two or thre of the moſt ſubſtauncyal men of the Shyre, ſhall be aſſygned kepers of the Peace by the kynges cōmiſſyon, and they with other learned in the lawe, ſhall heare and determyne felonyes and treſpaſſes commytted, and done agaynſt the Peace, and do reaſonable punyſſhement accordyng to lawe and reaſon Anno decimo octauo Edwardi tertii capi. 2.

¶ Iuſtyces of the peace ſhal holde theyr ſeſſyous .i.i. tymes in the yere at leaſt, that is to ſay
at the feaſte of the Annunciacion of our ladye, ſaynt Margaret, ſaynt Michael, and ſaincte Nycholas and more often, as ſhalbe thoughe requiſyte by the diſcrecyon of the ſayde Iuſtycers. Statutum de ſeruicientibꝰ. An. 25. Ed. 3. Capi. vlt Et an. 26 Ed. 3. capi. 12.

☞ In euery coūtye ſhalbe aſſigned a lorde. & thre or foure of the moll ſuſtancyal of the ſhyre with ſomme learned in the lawe, for the ſauegarde of the peace, and they haue power to enquere of myſdoers, ryottours, and other barratours, and them purſue, arreſte, take and chaſtyce after theyr treſpas, and to impryſon & duely punyſſhe them accordynge to the lawe & cuſtome of the Realme, and alſo to enquere of them that wander aboute, whiche wyll nat labour as they were wonte, and to take and arreſt al thoſe that they fynde culpable by enditement or ſuſpeccion, and to cōmyt them to pryſone, and they that be ſuſpeccions, and nat of good fame, to take ſuretye of theyr good abetynge before they goo out of pryſon. And alſo they maye at the Kyngess ſuyte heare, and determyne all Felonies and treſpaſſe committed within the ſame coūtye. Anno. 34. Edwardi. 3. Capitulo primo.

¶ In euery cōmyſſyon of the peace throughe the Realme, where nede ſhall be, two men of lawe of the ſame countye, ſhalbe aſſygned to go and procede to the delyueraunce of theues and felons, as often as they ſhall thynke it expedient the ſtatute therof is an. 17. R. 2. ca. vlt
er .

☞ In euery •• miſſyon of Iuſtyces of peas
there ſhall be but .vi. Iuſticers aſſygned with the Iuſtycers of Aſſyſe, and that the ſayde .vi. Iuſtycers ſhal holde theyr ſeſſyons euery quarter of the yere at leſt, and by thre dayes yf nede be, on payne to be punyſhed after the aduyſe of the Kynges counſayle at the ſuyte of any that wyll cōplayne. And they ſhall enquere of Mayres, Stewardes, Conſtables, and gaylours, yf they haue made dewe execucyon of the ſtatute made for ſeruantes labourers and beggers, & ſhal punyſſhe the punyſſheable by the payne of C. s̄ and they that be founde fautye, & nat punyſſheable by ye ſame payne, ſhalbe punyſſhed by theyr diſcrecyon. And euery of the ſayd Iuſtycers ſhall take .ii. i. s̄. a daye for theyr wages for the tyme of theyr ſayd ſeſſyons, and theyr clerke .ii. s. of the fynes and mercyamentes ryſynge and commynge of the ſame ſeſſyons, by the handes of the Shyryffes. And that the lordes of franchyſes ſhalbe contributours to the ſayd wages after the rate of their ꝑie of fynes & amercy amentes aforſayd an. 12. R. 2. Ca. 10.

☞ In euery countie ſhalbe aſſigned .viii. Iuſtycers of Peace, and theyr eſtreytes ſhall be doubled, and the one parte delyuere • by the ſayde Iuſticers to the ſhyryffe, to leuye the money ryſynge of the ſame ſeſſyons, & the ſhyryfe ſhall pay them theyr wages therof by Indenture. And that no Duke Earle, Baron, nor Baneret, althoughe they be aſſygned Iuſtyces of peace and ſytte in the ſeſſyons with the other .viii. ſhall take no wages. And that the Iuſtycers putte theyr names in the ſtreytes,
togyther with the nōbre of the dayes of theyr ſeſſyons, to the entent the ſhyryffes may know to whome to paye wages. The ſtatute therof is Anno. 14. R. 2. Capi. 11.

¶ No perſonne ſhalbe aſſygned to be Iuſtyce of the Peace in no countye within the realme of Englande, excepte he haue landes or ten̄nes to the value of .xx. li. by yere, and yf any be ordeyned hereafter Iuſtyce of the Peace in any countye that hathe nat landes and tenementes to the value aforeſayde, and dothe nat notifye the ſame to the chaūcellor of Englande for the tyme beynge, within a monethe after that he hathe knowledge of the ſayde cōmiſſyon, or yf he ſytte in the ſyſſyons, or make any warrant or precepte, by force of the ſame cōmyſſyon, he ſhall loſe .xx. li. And yet neuertheles he ſhall be put out of the commyſſyon: of whiche penaltie the kynge ſhall haue the one moyte, and he that wyl ſue for the kynge, the other halfe, and ſhal haue an accion to demaūde the penaltie by a wrytte of Dette at the cōmen lawe. Prouyded that this extende nat to ſuche Cytyes and borowes, that be coūtes encorporate of them ſelfe, nor to cyties, townes, and borowes, that haue Iuſtyce of peace of the inhabytantes by commyſſyon or graunt of the kynge or his progenytours. Prouyded alſo that yf there be nat men ſuffycyent, hauynge landes & tenementes to the value aforeſayde, lerned in the lawe and of good gouernaunce, within any ſuche coūtes that other lerned in the lawe ſhalbe made Iuſtyces of the Peace, by the dyſcrecyon of the
Chaūcellour of Englande, for the tyme beyng though they haue no landes to ſuche value. An no. 18. Henrici 6. capi. 11.
¶ Iuſtyces of peace ſhalbe ſworne, duely and without fauoure to kepe and put in erecucyon all the ſtatutes and ordinaūce touchynge their offyces. Anno. 13. R. 2. Capi. 7.

Forcyble entre.☞ Yf any man enter into landes and tenemen • es, and kepe them with force, the Iuſtyce of peace (after they be complayned vnto) ſhall take with them the power of the ſhyre, & go to the place where entre was made with force: & yf they fynde any that holdeth ſuche place forcybly the Iuſtyce ſhal comytte them to the next Gaole, there to abyde as conuycte by the Recorde of the ſame Iuſtyces, or Iuſtyce, vnto the tyme they haue made fyne and raāſome to the kynge, and that the ſhyre, as well the Shyryffe as other, ſhall be attendaunt to the ſayde Iuſtyices of peace, to go and ſtreagth ye ſayde Iuſtyces, to arreſte myſdoers, on payne of empriſonemēt and to make fine to the king And the ſame lawe and reaſon is for entres in to benefyces and offyces of the church, the ſtatutes is. Anno. 15. R. 2. Capi. 2.

¶ It is agreed that the ſtatut of Anno decimo quinto Ry. 2. of forcyble entre,Statute of forcyble entre ſhalbe holden in all poyntes. And bycauſe the ſayde Statute extendeth nat to entces into tenementes in peaſyble maner, & after kepte with forte, or yf thoſe perſons that entred by force be voyded & gone before the Iuſtyces of the Peace come, It is agreed yt yf any make ſuche forcyble entre into
landes or tenementes, or kepe them forcyably, that after complaynte made to the Iuſtices of peace they and euery of them haue power to enquere therof in conuenyent place by theyr diſcrecyon, at the coſtes of the partyes greued, and the perſones that made ſuche forcyble entres: ſhalbe preſented or voyded. And the ſayde Iuſtyces of peace ſhall make theyr warrantes & preceptes, dyrected to the ſhyriffe of the ſame ſhyre. &c. to do come before them ſuffycient and indifferēt perſons that dwel nereſt to the ſayd tenementes, to enquere of ſuche entres, and euery one that ſhalbe ſo empanelled before the ſayde Iuſtycers, ſhall haue landes and tenementes to the value of .xl. s. by the yere aboue the charges. And the ſhyrif ſhal retourne iſſues vpon euery of them, the fyrſte daye of returne of the precept .xi. s. the ii. daye .xl. s. ye .iii. C. s. & at euery day after double. And yf the ſhyriffe or baylyfe of franches, hauynge returne of the kynges wrytte, be ſlacke, & make nat execucyon of the ſayd preceptes, he ſhall loſe for eurry defaute .xx. li. and make fyne to the kynge: and as well Iuſtycers of peace, as Iuſtyces of Aſſ. haue power to heare & determyne ſuch default & neclygences of the ſayd ſhyryffes & baylyffes as well by byll at the ſuyte of the partie, as by endytement taken for the kynge onely. And yf the ſhyryffe or baylyffe be duelye atteint in this behalfe by endytement or byll, he that wyll ſue for hym ſelfe, and the kynge ſhal haue the half of the forfayture of .xx. li. with hys coſtes and expences. And that, ſuche proces ſhalbe made
againſt them as in an accion of Treſpas with force. An. 8. H. 6. Cap. 9.

Roytius aſſemble.¶ Where any, ryot, rout or aſſēble of people is had agaynſt the lawe, two or thre of the Iuſtycers of the peace, and the ſhyryffe or vnderſhyryffe ſhall take ſuche power of the ſhyre, as ſhalbe nede to arreſte them, and the ſame Iuſtices, ſhyryffe, & vnderſhyriffe ſhal haue power to recorde the mater, as they fynde it, and the perſonnes beynge yll doers, ſha • be conuycte by theyr recorde. And yf it happen the ſame yf doers to be departed before the Iuſtyces, ſhyryffe and vnderſhyriffe come: than they ſhal enquere therof within a moneth imm • diatly after ſuch ryotte, aſſemble, or route of the people ſo done, and they ſhal heare & determyne it accordynge to the lame of the lande: and yf the verdyte he nat founde within a moneth, they ſhall certyfye the kynge or hys coūſel of all the circūſtances within a moneth, whiche certyfycat ſhalbe of the ſame effecte, as thoughe it had be foūde by twelue men. And yf any myſdoers wyll trauers the mater, than the certyfycat and the trauers ſhall be ſente into the kynges Benthe: there to be tried. And the iuſtyce of peace, dwel lynge moſt nere in any countye, where any ſuche ryotte of people ſhalbe here after, togyther with the ſhyryffe, or vnderſhyryffe of the ſame county • , and alſo the iuſtyces of Aſſyſe for the tyme that they ſhalbe there in theyr Seſſyons in caſe that any ſuche ryotte aſſemble or route ſhalbe made in theyr preſence, ſhall do executyon of the ſayde Statute, ach • , on payne to
pay .C. li. to the kyng, as oft as they ſhal fau • to execute the ſame ſtatute. An. 13. H 4. Ca vlt
er ¶ Iuſtyces of the peace in euery ſhyre, in two of theyr Seſſyons holden bytwene Eaſter and Myghelmas, ſhall make ꝓclamacyon by theyr diſcrecyon, after the derthe of vytayles, howe much a maſon, a carpenter, a tayler, and other craftes men, workmen, & laborers ſhal take by the day, as well in Auguſte as in other tymes of the yere, with meate and drynke, or without meate and drynke, bytwene the two Seſſyons aforeſayde. And that euery man obeye theſe proclamacions, from tyme to tyme, as a thyng made by ſtatute. And all vitaylers ſhalbe take theyr wynnynge after the diſcrecion and limittacyon of the ſayd iuſtices of ye peace on payne to be greuouſly punyſſhed after the diſcrecion of the ſayd iuſtyces of peace where no payne a force tyme hath ben limitted on the ſayd vitaylers. Anno. 13. R. 2. Capi. 8.

Fugitiue laborce.¶ Iuſtyces of the peace haue power to ſende theyr wryties for fugityue laborers, to eche ſhyryffe of this realme of Englande, and to make ſuche proces as the ſtatute requereth, to bryng them before thē, to anſwere to our ſoueraygne lorde the kynge and to the parties, of the contemptes and treſpaſſes done contrary to the ordinaunce and ſtatutes in that behalfe, prouyded in lyke maner as the ſayde Iuſtyces haue power to ſende to any ſhyryffe for theues end •
ted before them. And alſo that all the ſtatutes and ordynaūces of laborers, ſeruantes, & artyfycers made in tyme paſt and nat repelled, b •
exemplyfyed vnder the great ſeale, and ſent to euery ſhyre of the realme of Englande to proclayme them in full countie, and after this proclamacyon ſo made, the ſhyryffe ſhall cauſe the ſame exēplifycacyon, to him directed, to be delyuered to the Iuſtyces of the peace, or to one of them, to remayn with the ſame Iuſtyces, that be or ſhalbe for the better putrynge of the Statutes and ordynaunce in execucyon. And that Iuſtyces of peace in euery countye named of the Quorum be reſſeant within the ſame coū tye, excepte Lordes named in the commyſſyon and alſo excepte Iuſtyces of the one henche & of the other, the chyefe baron of the Eſcheker, ſergeantes at the lawe, and the kynges atturney, for the tyme that they ſhalbe attendynge and occupyed in the Kynges courtes, or other wyſe enbuſed in the kynges ſeruyce, and ſhall holde theyr ſeſſyons .iiii. tymes in the yere, that is to ſay, in the fyrſt weke after the feaſt of S. Myghell, the fyrſt weke after the Epiphanye, the fyrſt weke after the (clauſum Paſche) and the fyrſt weke after ſaint Thomas day, and of tener yf neceſſyte requyre. And iuſtyces of the peace haue power to examyne all labourers, artyfycers, and ſeruaūtes, by theyr othes of thynges by them done contrary to the ordynance & Statutes, and to punyſſhe them therupon, as well as vpon enqueſt. An. 2. H. 5. capi. 4. et an. 34. Edwardi. 3. capi. 10.

¶ Plees, ſuytes, and proces, commenced before Iuſtyces of the peace, ſhall nat be dyſcontynued by newe commiſſyons of peace made to
other Iuſtycers, but thoſe plees and proceſſes ſhall ſtande in theyr ſtrengthe. And the Iuſtyces in the ſame newe commiſſyons ſo aſſygned after that they haue the recordes of the ſayde plees & proceſſe afore them, ſhal haue power & auctoryte to continue the ſayde plees and proceſſes, and the ſame and al other dependyng to heare & fynally determyne, in lyke maner as ye other Iuſtyces mought & ought to haue don if no newe cōmiſſ. had ben made, an. 11. H. 6. ca. 6 ¶ Iuſtyces of peace haue power to enquere. heare and determyne, in caſe yf men of waies by daye or by nyght come into the Shyres of Herforde, Shreweſburye, Gloceſter, and other Shyres adioynynge, and take men with them, and kepe them in Wales in the Mountaynes, vnto the tyme that they haue payde ce •
tayne ſommes of money. And yf the ſayde myſdoers wyll nat appere, vnto the tyme that they be outlawed, than ſhall the ſame Iuſtyces wrytte letters vnto the officers of the ſeignoryes, where ſuche myſdoers dwel of the out lagarye vpon them pronounced, and the ſame offycers vpon that certification, to take the bodyes of thoſe outlawes, and do execucion vpō them in the ſame ſeignorye, as the lawe requyreth in that caſe, without tyne or raunſome in this be halfe to be made. Statut
er . 2. Anno. 2. Henrici. 5. ca. 5.
