que idem I. ad reſpondendum coram Iuſticiarium predictum, de murdet
er et felon̄ prediet
er , ſecundum conſuetudinem regn: noſtri Anglie deducatur, et compellatur: et hoc nullatenus omitt
er , ſeu vnus veſtrum omitt
er , ſub periculo incumbente. Teſte I. S. vno Iuſtic. noſtrorum predictum in tranſtino ſancti Mariini. An. regni regis Henrici ſeptimi. 20.

div.head: ¶ Breue per Iuſtic̄ gaol.
div.p:
¶ M. N. Miles et ſocii ſui Iuſtic. domini r •
gis et gaolam ſuam caſtri ſui de T. de priſonibus in ea exiſlē
• ibus deliberandn̄ aſſignū, vic. Eſſex, ſaltm̄ Et parte dicti domini Regis tibi precipimus, ꝙ Venire facias coram nobis apd C. die lune proximo ante feſtum ancti Iacobi Apoſtoli omnes priſones in gaola predicta exiſten̄, vna cum corumattachiamentis, & aliis ad miniculis priſones tilos qualit
er cun
que tangent
er & de viſum curſliber ville & loci, vnde telonie, de quibus iid priſones indictati, appellati, vel arrectati eriſtūt, fact
er fuer̄, tam infra libertat
er
quam extra, viginti quatuor liberos & legales hoīes per quos rei veritas melius ſcire poterit, & qui priſones p̄dict
er nulla aſſin̄ atringunt, vna cum quotuor hominibus & p̄poſitum ville & ſocii eorum; ad faciendum ea q̄ ex parte dict
er domini regis tunc ibid iniungenr̄: Publice etiam proclamare facias ꝑ totam ba • ltuam tuam, quod omnes illi, qui ſequi voluerit verſus priſones ꝑdict
er ꝙ • unc ſint ibi vſus eos (ꝓut iuſtum fuerit) ꝓſecniuri. Scir̄ facias etiam omnibus Iuſtic. pacis, Coron̄, ſeneſc̄, dominorum & magnatum, at balliuis liberatum, and faciēdum id qd ad officia ſ • u pertinent ad raciēdum. Et iuvicicomes vel ſubuic. tuus vna cum balliuis vl miniſtris veſtris, tunc ſitis in propriis ꝑſonis veſtris, adfaciēdum quod ad officium veſtrum pertinet in hac parte. Et habeas ibi nomina predictorum Iuſticiariorū pacis, coronatorū ſeneſcallorum, & palliuorum, & eorum per quotis
inde ſcir̄ feceris, breue Domini Regis tun • termittendo, quod inde tibi venerit & hoc p̄ceptum Datum apud Weſtmonaſterium decimo die menſis Iulii. Anno regni regis. H. 7. ca. 21.

div.head: ¶ The fourme and maner of the Iuſtyces of Peace charge.
div.p: YE ſhall enquere of Herytykes and lollardes,Herytykes & lollardes. & ſuch as kepe erronyous opinions, teache & preache ye ſame contrary to the tayth and lawes of the Churche, or kepe any ſcooles therof, in hurt and preiudyce of the fayth, ye ſhall do vs to wete of theyr names, and of theyr opynyons, and howe longe they haue contynued therin. Vide ſcatutū. An, 2. H. 5. Capi. 7,

¶ Two Iuſtyces of peace of the ſhyre,Heryſye. where it ſhall happen any perſon or perſons to be accuſed, preſented, or indyted of heryſye, may by theyr diſcrecyons, in defaut of the ordynaryes lette ſuche perſon or perſons to bayle, by .iiii. ſuffycyent ſuertyes, bounde to the Kynges vſe by oblygacyon or recognyſaunce, to appere before the ordynaries at ſuche dayes, tyme, and places, as ſhall be lymytted in the ſayde bondes by the ſayde two Iuſtyces, excepte the ordynaryes canne and do declare to the Kynges hyghneſſe, and to hys coūſayle, a reaſonable cauſe, that the ſayd perſon or perſons accuſed or preſented of Heryſye, ſhulde nat be lette to
bayle Anno. 25 H. 8. Capi. 14. Marke • in chu • chyardes.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of all them that kep • any fayres, or market • rs, in church • yardes, o • in any other holy place, where any ſekynge is, and howe longe they haue contynu • d • herin, the Statute thereof if of Edwarde the thyrde made at Wyncheſter. And alſo in the ſtatute made at wyncheſter, ye. 13. yere of E • . 1 is was defended, that feyres ſhulde no more be kept in churcheyardes

Coūterfetyng of coyne.¶ Ye ſhall enquere of them that counterfeyt • the kynges coyne, or yf there be any falſe money and payment made therwith. And of them that brynge falſe money into thys Realme, or that counterfeyte the coyne of another realme whiche by the kynges ſufferaunce is curraunt within this Realme, ye ſhall do vs to were.

And of them that elyppe, waſſhe, fyle, or other wyſe falſytye the money of this Realme And this ſemeth to be hyghe treaſon, for the ſtatut • ſayth, that he is a traytour • o the kynge & hy • realme Anno tercio Hē
•• ct qu • nti ſtatuto ſcd •
Capi. 6. et. 7.

¶ And the ſame .iii. yere of the ſayd Kynge, it was ordeyned t • at galyhalfepens, ſo (kynne • dodkyns,Galyhalfpens and all money of Scotlande ſhuld • be all pu • out, and who that maketh, vyethe, coynethe, or bryngethe into thys realme galyhalfpens, ſoſkyns and dodkyns, ſhall be pumyſſhed as a felon, and he that taketh or payeth ſuche mon • y, ſhall loſe an C s̄. whereof th • Kynge ſhall haue the one half • , and he tha • wyll ſewe the other halfe. And tha • Iu •••
cers
of Peace in euery Shyre of this Realme, haue power to enquyre therof, to heare and determyne the ſame.

☞ Alſo of thē that ſlee theyr mayſter, that is for to ſay theyr ſoueraynge, as wyfe her huſbāde, ſeruant his mayſter, or any, vnder whoſe obeyſance he is: the cauſe is, the mayſter hathe to hym more truſte then to a ſtraunger. Vide ſtatutum inde. Anno viſecimoquinto Edwardi tertii Cap ſecundo.

¶ Alſo Iu • tyces of peace haue ful power and auctoryte in theyr ſeſſyons to enquyre of trayterours murderers and murders of poyſonyng as well as of the counterfeytyng of coyne of a ny outwarde realme,Of ſuche as ſieye theyr ſoueraygne ſuffered to roune and go within this realme by the kinges aſſent and to make proces therupon by Capias only for poyſonynge is adiudged & deamed as hyghe treaſon by act of perlyament made. Auno viſecimo ſecundo Hērici. 8. Capi. 9.

¶ And ye ſhall enquyre,Poyſonnynge. yf any man be ſlayne or murdered by the day, whether the murderer vs taken by the towneſhyp, where the murder was done, for yf he be nat, the towneſhyp ſhall be amercyed. Anno. 3. H. 7. Copi. 1.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of all them that caſt any bylles into any mans houſe,Threttes ſo brenne a mans houſe. in the whiche bylles is conteyned, that yf the ſame perſonne brynge nat a certayne ſomme of money, or laye it 〈◊〉 a certayne place and houre, his houſe ſhal be br • nt, and the money be nat there layde, the houſe • s brent, this is hyghe treaſon. The ſtatute therof is. An. 8. H. 6. Capi. 6.

Murder and man ſlaught.¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of all maner of felons bycauſe ſome of them ben more heynous than ſome, as murder and manſlaughter. Murder is properly where a man by malyce prepenſed lyeth in a wayte to ſlee a man, and accordynge to that malycyous intent & purpoſe, he ſleeth hym ſo that he, whiche is ſlayne, maketh no defence agaynſte hym, for yf he do, it is manſlaughter and no murder, the offence of thys murder is more h • ynous than the offence of other felonyes, for yf the kynge ꝑtaunte him a pardō of all maner of felonies, it auayleth him nought for murder, but yf it make expreſſe mē cyon of murders. And the Statute therof is Anno. 13. R. 2. Capi. 1.

¶ And manſlaughter is,Chaunce medley. where two men, or mo mete, and by chaunce medley, they fall at affraye, ſo that one of them ſleeth another, it is but felonye in hym ſelfe, and therfore yf any ꝑſon be defectyue in this wyſe, make your preſentment accordynge. vt ſ.

¶ Alſo ye ſhal enquire of rape,Rape. Rape is where a man rauyſſheth or taketh a mans wyfe, wydowe, or mayde agaynſt her wyll, and hath to do with her agaynſt her wyll; albert that ſhe aſſent afterwarde, yet it is Felonye, & without the kynges charter make mencyon of rape, it auayleth hym nought. The Statute therof is Weſtm̄. ii. Capi. 34.

☞ There be alſo Felons,Roberie. that contryue takynge awaye of mennes goodes, as by robbery and theyr Robbery is where a man lyethe by the kynges hygh • waye to market townes, in
woddes, dythes, or in any other ſecrete places, where people come forth by, and robbeth thē, albeit that he taketh away, but the value of a peny or leſſe, it is felonye, for the malapertneſſe of the dede and ie • pardye that a man is in of his lyfe, where it ſo taken away from his perſon cauſeth the offence to be greatter, then yf it had ben theuyſhely ſtollen.

☞ Thefte is where a thef ſtealeth a mannes gooddes in his chamber or in his cloſe,Thefte or any other place yf the vaine paſſe .xiiii. d. it is felonye, and yf it be nat paſſynge the value of .xii. d it is but petyte larceny, or brybery, for the whiche he ſhal nat dye, but make a fyne to the kīg, but yf it can be foūde at diners tymes, that he hath taken goodes of that value, and more, thē he ſhall dye therfore.

☞ Alſo if there be any mā,Burgul •
rye. that burneth his neyghbours houſe malyciouſly by daye or by nyght, it is felonye. Alſo of them that breake houſes by nyghte, to the intente to robbe, thoughe they take nothynge awaye, it is burgulary, whiche in it ſelfe is felony, bycauſe the lawe gyueth to colour to breake a mans houſe by nyght.

Clerkes cōuicte.¶ Clerkes conuicte of pety Treaſon, wylfull murder or robberies done by or nere the hyghe way. &c. ſhall make no purgacyon, excepte they do fynde it. ſuffycyent ſuertyes, euery of them hauynge lanoes, or other heredytamentes of charter holde of entherytaunce to the yerely value of .cx. vi. s. viii. pens or els be worth .xx li. in • ouayble ſubſtance, eche of the •• to be bounce
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
in .xx. li. and hym ſelfe in .xl. by recognyſaunce before two Iuſtyces of peace, within the ſame ſhyre, where ſuche offences were commytted wherof one of them to be of the Quorum, that ſuche conuycte ſhalbe of good aberyng, which Iuſtices ſhal certifye euery ſuche recogniſaūce into the Kynges benche within .iiii. monethes nexte after the takynge therof, vpon payne of C. s. for euery defaute. Anno. 23. H. 8. Ca. 1.

¶ Alſo yf any gaoler,Gaylour Shyryffe, or other perſone that hathe the kepynge of any gaole, by to great dureſſe of impryſonement & by payne make any pryſoner that he hathe in his warde become an appelioure agaynſte hys wyll, and therof be attaynted before the Kynges Iuſtyces, he ſhall haue iudgemēt of lyfe and of membre. Anno. 14. E. 3. Capi. 10.
¶ Iuſtyces of Peace ſhal nat impryſon men, but in the common gaole, ſauynge to all them, that haue gayles,Making and mendynv̄e of gayles. theyr lybertye. An. 5. Henrici quarti Capitulo. 10.

¶ The Iuſtyces of the peace, or the moſt part of them in euery of the ſhyres of Eſſer. Suffolke, Dorē, Suſſex, Surrey, Notyngham, Glouē. Bedforde, Buch, Huntyngdon, wylſh, Kente, Warwyke, Stafforde, Oxen̄. Barkeſ. Leyceſter, Rutlāde, Lyncoln̄, Herford, Northhampton, Salop̄. Norforke, and Cornewayll, and Derby ſhall within a yere after the ende of this parlyament, within the lymyttes of theyr commyſſyous, appoynt the townes and places for a commen Iayle newely to be made, for the edifyeng whe • of the ſayd Iuſtices withī theyr
lymyttes ſhall haue power to call before them the hyghe Conſtables, tythyngmen, or borowe holders of euery hundred, lath or wapentake, and in theyr preſence by theyr aſſente, or of the moſt parte of them, ſhall agree vpon certayne ſuffycyent ſommes of money by theyr dyſcrecyon for the makynge of a newe Iayle in the ſhyre where they be Iuſtyces, and for the ſame entent to taxe euery perſon reſyant within the ſame ſhyre, as well within lybertyes, as without, that hathe landes, tenementes, rentes, or annuyties of freholde to the clere yerely value of xl. s. or beynge worthe in mouable goodes, xx. li. to ſuche ſommes of money as they ſhall thynke conuenyent, and there vpon to aſſygne ſuche nombre of Collectours for leuyeng their of, as ſhal ſeme beſt by theyr diſcrecions which Collectours ſhall haue power to diſtrayne euery perſonne as ſhalbe ſet or taxed by the ſayde Iuſtyces of peace. And yf the partye refuſe to paye within .x. dayes nexte after ſuche diſtryſſe takē, the Collectours may ſelle the dyſtreſſe by the apprayſement of .iiii. honeſt perſons for the paymēt therof. And the ſayd Iuſtices of peace within theyr lymyttes, haue auctorytye to appoynt .ii. honeſt perſons to ſuruey, ſc, and prouyde that ye ſayd iayles be ſuer & ſubſtācyally made, to whoſe handes the Collectours ſhall pay the money by them collected of the kynges ſubiecres, by the appoyntment of the ſayd Iuſtyces of peace, or .vi. of them. And as well euery collectour as the .ii. ſurueyours, theyr heires executours, and adminyſtratours ſhall make a
true accompie to the ſayde Iuſtyces of Peace whan they ſhalbe requyred, and yf they refuſe ſo to do, or to page or imploye the money as is lymytted, the ſayde Iuſtices of peace haue power to commytte them to warde, yf the partes be preſent, yf they be abſent, to make out their Attechementes vnder theyr ſeal • (to be returnable before the ſame Iuſtyces at a daye and place by thē lymytted) directed to the ſhyryffes of the ſhyre where the partie ſhalbe abydynge, and the ſhyryffes ſhall attache, and perſonally brynge the offenders before the ſayde Iuſtices accordynge to the tenour of the Attachement, orels declare by his returne a reaſonable cauſe why he can nat ſo doo, vpon payne, for euery defaute contrarye to this acre to loſe. C. s. to the kynge. And vpon apparance, of euery ſuche perſon attached, the ſayd Iuſtyces or .vi. of thē haue auctoryte to commytte them to Pryſon, there to remayne without bayle or maynpryſe tyll they haue truely accompted and payde all ſuche ſommes of money as came to theyr handes by auctoryte of this acte. The ouerplus of the money nat ſpente on the Iayles, to be employd in almes to the pryſoners commytted to the ſayd iayles, by the diſcrecyons of the ſayde Iuſtyces, or the more parte of them, as longe as it wyll laſt. Prouyded that this acte charge nat perſons within cyties, townes, or borowes corporate, whiche haue commen Iayles for Felons taken in the ſame, & Iuſtyces of peace for delyuerance of ſuche felons. And Iuſtyces of peace in euery ſhyre afore named may lymyt
to euery collectoure and perſon for leuyenge of the money tared, and ſurueynge of the makyng of the ſayde iayles, reaſonable ſōmes for their labours. Anno. 23. H. 8. Cap. 2.

☞ Alſo yf there be any perſon that vſeth to multyplye eyther with golde or ſyluer,Multiplienge. or vſe ye craft of multyplycacion, & yf any the ſame do, that he incurte the payne of felony in this caſe, Anno. 5. H. 4. Capi. 4.

¶ Alſo of them that cutte out the tonges, or put out the eyes of any of the kynges lyege people,Cuttyng of tonges and that duely proued & founde that ſuche dede was done of malyce prepenſed, they ſhall in curre the payne of felonye.

¶ And yf any ſoudyoure, man of armes or other, leauynge his Captayne in the kynges ſeruyce,Soldyours. and in the aduenture of the warre, departeth awaye without lycence of his Capitayne ſhalbe punyſſhed as a Felon accordynge to the Statute made. Anno octauo Hentici ſexti Capitulo vltimo.

☞ And yf any that is no Captayne, reteyned to ſerue the kynge on the ſee or beyonde the ſee departe out of the kynge ſeruyce without lycence of his Captayne, that ſuche departynge be taken, demed, and adiudged Felony and he that ſo offendeth ſhal nat haue the benefyce of his clergye. And that Iuſtyces of the Peace where ſuche offendours ſhall be taken haue power to euquere, heare, and determyne that offence, and it is to be tryed in the ſame Shyre. Anno. 7. H. 7. Capi. 1.

☞ Alſo another lyke ſtatut was made. Anno
tertio Henrici octaui Capi. 5.

Acceſſaries to felons.¶ There bene dyuers maners of acceſſaryes and require dyuers preſentmētes. One maner acceſſarye is where a man receyueth a Felon, knowynge him to haue done felonye, comforteth, and abbettethe, procurethe, and ſtere the, but and he byd hym ſteale an horſe, he is pryncypalle. Alſo yf after ſuche felonyes, or robberies done, whethere there be any freſſhe ſute made accordynge to the Statute of Wyncheſter, for that Statute wyll, that yf the partye robbed come to the nexte towneſhyppe adioynynge, and there make relacyon of hys robberye, they of thoſe townſhyps ſhal make freſſhe ſuyte from towne to towne, and from countye to countye, to take the felons, & to brynge thē to the next gaole, and yf the towneſhyppes, after the relacyon made to them, wyll nat make freſſhe ſuyte, that than they ſhall aunſwere the partye ſo robbed, and that within fortie dayes after the felony ſo done, and the ſtatute therof is. Anno. 18. Edwardi terii. Capi. 11.

Nobruſh to growe by hyghe wayes.¶ Alſo that men ſhulde nat be ſodaynely takē by ſuch robbers, it is ordeyned by the ſame ſtatute of Wyncheſter, that there ſhall no bruſſhe growe two hundreth foote of euery ſyde of ye waye, and yf the Lorde wyll nat ſuffer them of the countrey to cutte downe the ſhrubbes, yf any perſone be robbed, the lorde ſhall anſwere to the partye robbed, and yf there be any murder, than the lorde ſhall be atented at the kynges wyll, and natwithſtandynge the countrey ſhall cutte downe the ſhrubbes by the ſame ſtatute
of Wyncheſter.

Anoyſances of brydges.¶ Iuſtyces of peace in euery ſhyre, fraunches or borowe, or .iiii. of them at the leaſte, wherof one to be of the Quorum, haue power to enquyre, heare and determyne in the generall ſeſſyons of peace, of all annoyſances of brydges broken in hyghe wayes, and to make ſuch proceſſe and payne agaynſt thoſe yt ſhulde amende theym, as the Iuſtyces of the Kynges benche vſe to do, or as it ſhall ſeme by theyr diſcrecion to be neceſſarye for the ſpedye amendynge of ſuche brydges. Anno. 22. H. 8. capi. 5.

Hoſtries of felons¶ Alſo yf there be any perſon, that kepeth hoſtryes in ſuburbes, vplandyſſhe townes, and herborowe any perſonne, without he wyll anſwere for hym, the ſtatute therof is of Wyncheſter.

Eſcapes of felons¶ Alſo yf any Shyryffe, Gaoler, or any other perſon haue letten wyllfully eſcape any Felon it is felonye. And lyke wyſe yf any Bayly, conſtable, or ſhyryffe, or any other haue taken any man for ſuſpeccyon of felonye and let hym go, for he ſhulde haue brought hym to the next gaole. But in ſuche caſe yf a watche man take any ſuche perſone, he may enquyre of his good name and fame, and yf he fynde hym of good name and fame, he may lette him go. And yf a felon eſcape out of the kepynge of any Gaoler agaynſt hys wyll, it is fynable, the fyne is an C. s. and yf any perſonne conuycte, and in the pryſone of the ordinarye, eſcape out of the pryſon, the fyne is an. C. li. &c.

¶ Alſo of all maner of extorcyon done, yf the
Shyryffe, Eſchetour, or Conſtable, take any thynge for execurynge of theyr offyces, If the ſhyryffe take any man by Capias, the fees is two ſhyllynges and .iiii. pens, yf he take any more, it is extorcyon. &c.

Execuciō of ordinaries.¶ Alſo of all extorcyons done by Ordinaryes for takynge exceſſyuely for prouynge of teſtamentes, for he ſhulde take but .ii. s. vi. or .v. s̄. and whether he drawe the kynges people into the ſpirytuall courtes for cauſes that ſhulde he determyned in the kynges courtes, the ſtatute therof is. Anno. 13. Ed. 3. Capi. 4.

¶ And where the gooddes of the teſtatour do nat amounte aboue. C. s̄. to take but .vi. pens for the probate of the teſtament. And whan the goodes of the teſtatour do amounte aboue the value of an▪ C. s̄. and excede nat the value of .xi li. to take for the probacyon, regeſtrynge cealynge, and wryttynge of any ſuche teſtamēt but onely thre. s̄. vi. pens. And where no gooddes amounte aboue .rl. pounde, but onely fyue ſhylynges to be taken accordynge to the ſtatut therof made. Anno. 12. H. 8. Capi. 5.
¶ Alſo of them that take extorcyon with gay lour for warrant of any perſon, to the entente to ſuffre hym to dwell in the countrey by hym without trouble.

¶ Alſo yf Coroners take any thyng for yt executynge of theyr offyce, the ſtatute doth prohybit .ii.Forcyble entre. Weſtm̄. 2. Capi. 10. But the ſtatute of Henry the .iiii. gyueth to hym a marke for hys laboure.

¶ Alſo yf any perſonne haue entred into any
mans freholde with force, albeit he kepeth i • in peaſyble maner, yet the lawe wyll that he ſuffre impryſonment of his bodye, and be raū ſomed at the kynges wyll, the Stature therof is. Anno. 5. R. 2 Capi. 6. Ryottes.

¶ Alſo of all ryottes done, that is to ſaye, of them that accōpany them ſelf in forcyble araye agaynſt the kynges peace, puttynge the kynge people in feare. Alſo them that lye in awayte to beate the Kynges people in the hyghe ways ſo arayed, all thoughe they beate no man▪ yet they ſhalbe punyſſhed. And yf they beate any man, make your preſentment accordyngly.

¶ Alſo of them that accompany them ſelfe in any lyuerye, as bonettes, hattes, Iackettes,Liuerye. or any other thynge lyke, and euery of them is ſworne to a byde and maynteyn others quarels and to holde with other. The ſtatute therof is Anno. 1. R. 2. Capi 6.

¶ Alſo of al haſarders, that ſlepe by daye,Haſarders. and wake by nyght, and cuſtomably hauntynge the tauerners, nat hauynge whereon to lyue, and no man woteth from whenſe they comme, nor wyther they wyll. &c.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquere of them that come in fortyble aray,Forcyble arraye where cōgregacion of people is in fayres markettes, or in any other places, or that they ryde or go armed, other by nyght, or by daye, it is a prouocacion to diſturbe the peace, wherfore it is nat lawfull any ſo to ryde or go in any place, excepte the kynge mynyſters in doynge and executynge their offyces, the ſtatute therof is. Anno. 2. Ed. 3. Capi. 3.
¶ And by the ſame ſtatute it is ꝓhibited, that ſuche perſonnes, forcybly arrayed, ſhulde nat comme before the Kynges Iuſtyces, in doynge theyr offyces.
vnlawful wepons.¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of all them that beare launcegayes in rydynge or goynge within the lande, for that is ꝓhibyted by the ſtatute made Anno. 20. R. 2. Capi. 1.

Conſtables for executige of theyr offyces.¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre yf the conſtables haue done and executed theyr offyces on them that beare wepens agaynſt the lawe, for the ſtatute of Richarde (Anno. 20. Ca. 6. wyll that no ſeruaunt of huſbandrye, labourer, nor ſeruaunt of artyfycer, nor of vytaylier ſhall weare any baſelarde, dagger, nor ſworde, vpon payne to forfayte the ſame, without it be in tyme of warre in the defence of the Realme of Englande, And the Shyryffes, Mayre, Baylyffes, and Cōſtables haue power by the ſayd ſtatute to ſeyſe the ſayde baſelardes and them to kepe and preſent before the Iuſtyces of the Peace at the ſeſſions, and to preſent their names that beare them.

¶ Alſo by the ſame ſtatute before nowe rehe •
ſed,Vnlawe full games. and the ſayde Chapiter, no labourer, nor ſeruaunt of artyfycer, ſhall playe at the tenys, cayles, foreball. &c. But to haue bowes and arowes, and them vſe on holy dayes. The ſtatute of Henry the fourth confyrmeth thys ſtatute, and wyll, that the Mayre, Baylyffes, and Cōſtables haue power to arreſt ſuche men, a empryſon them by the ſpace of ſyxe dayes, And yf the ſayde Mayres, and Baylyffe, doo nat
execucyon, for euery tyme that they faute, to forfayte .xx. s. and the conſtable to forfayt .vi. s̄. and .viii. d. An. 20. H. 4. Capi .iiii.
¶ Alſo of al thē that haue made any reſcous agaynſt the ſhyryffe, baylyffe,Reſcous or any other offycer in executynge of any warrantes. &c.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre, yf there be any man, of what condicyon that he be of,Laborers free or bonde myghty in body, and within the age of xl. yeces, nat hauynge wherof to lyue, neyther bycourſe of marchaundyſe, nor vſynge any handy craft, nor hath no lande, whereupon he may occupy hym ſelf with tyllyng, and is requyred to ſerue, and refuſeth contrary to the lawe, the lawe wyll, that the Baylye and Conſtable, and ſuch as haue the rule, haue auctoryte & power to put them in warde, there to abyde tyll they wyll be iuſtifyed and ordered by the lawe, the ſtatut therof is An. 23. Edwardi. 3. Capitulo. 1 & Anno. 34. Edwardi. 3. Capi. 11.

☞ Alſo yf there be any labourer,Laborers deꝑrynge that departeth out of one hundreth vnto another, or oute of one wapentake vnto another, vnder the coloure of pylgremage, without a letter patent vnder the Kynges ſeale, prouynge that he departeth lawfully, and that he goeth vpon pylgremage, the ſtatute therof is. Anno. 12. Ri. 3. Ca. 3. and that no man kepe nor harburge no ſuche vagarauntes ouer a nyght, but yf he be ſycke, eodem Anno.

¶ Alſo that no man able to ſerue or laboure begge,Beggers but thoſe that haue a ſpecyall lycence of the Kynge, except men of Relygyon, and heremyttes
approued, hauynge letters teſtemonyals of theyr Ordinaryes, and they that do th • contrarye ſhalbe demeaned as laborers & ſeruauntes departynge without lycence. Anno. 21. R. 2. Capi. 6.

☞ Alſo thoſe beggers that ben impotent to ſerue,Beggers impotent ſhalbe abydynge in thoſe Cytyes and townes where they dwelled, and nat to begge out therof, but yf ſo be the Cities and townes may nat or wyl nat fynde them, than they ſhall goo into ſome other Cyties and townes withe in the hundreth or wapentake, or towne where they were before, and the Statute therof is vt ſupra.

¶ Iuſtyces of Peace of all and ſynguler the ſhyres of Englande,Biggers ſhal as often as nede ſhal requyre, deuyde them ſelues within the lymyttes of theyr commyſſyons, and make dilygent ſerche and enquerie, of all aged, poore, and impotent perſons, compelled of neceſſytie to lyue by almes, and after and vpon ſuche ſerche made, ſhall enable to begge within the lymyttes of theyr deuiſyons, ſuche of the ſayde impotent perſons as they ſhall thynke conuenyente to lyue of the charytie and almes of the people, and commaunde the ſayde aged and impotent perſons by them enabled, that none of them begge without the lymyttes to them appoynted, and ſhall regeſter and wrytte the names in a byll or rolle indenced, of euery ſuch aged and impotent perſonne, the one parte to remayne with them ſelfe, and the other in the kepynge of the Cuſtos rocu • orum. And by
cauſe it is ouer longe here to reſyte al that Iuſtyces of peace are bounde to do cōcernynge aged, poore, impotent perſons, and ſtronge valyam beggers. I referre them to the ſtatute in that caſe prouyded. Anno. 32. H. 8. Capi. 12.

¶ Alſo they that ſaye,Soldyors takē. they were taken out of the Realme, and there impryſoned, ſhall bryng letter teſtymonyall of the Capitaynes where they were abydynge, or of the Mayres or baylyffes where they aryued, & the ſame Mayres and Baylyffes ſhall enquyre with whom they haue dwelled, and in what place theyr dwellynge is in Englande • . And that the ſame Mayres and Bailyffes make them letters patentes vnder the ſeale of theyr offyce, teſtyfyenge the daye of theyr arryuynge, and where they haue ben, and to cauſe them to ſweare to holde the ryght way towardes their countrey except they haue letters patētes vnder the kynges great ſeale to do otherwyſe. Anno decimoſecundo Richardi ſecundi Capi. 8.

¶ Alſo that no man giue almes to any perſon that is able to ſerue,Almes 〈◊〉
vnder the payne of impreſonment, and the Statute therof is. Anno. 23. Edwardi. 3. Capi. 7.

¶ Alſo that no man ſet his ſonne to craft, but yf he may dyſpende .xx. ſhyllynges by the yere,Children to craft. and he ſhulde haue a wrytynge vnder the ſeale of two Iuſtyces of the peace, vnto the Mayre Baylyffe or wardeyne of the craft, certifyenge that he may ſo diſpende. And that no man take any to the contrary, vnder the payne of an hundreth ſhyllynges to be forfayt, to the kynge
and he that wyll ſue ſhall haue the one halfe and the kynge the other halfe, and alſo the couenaunt to be voyde, and the ſtatute therof i • Anno. 7. H. 4. Capi. 17.

Hauigue ſtockes.¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre, whethere euery tow • ſhyppe haue theyr ſtockes for to punyſſhe treſpaſſours that do agaynſt the lawe, & in eſpec • all them, that wyll nat obey the ſtatutes of labourers, the payne of the townſhyppe, nat hauynge ſtockes is an. C. s̄. the Statue therof i • Anno.Agaynſte threſhers 7. H. 4. Capi. 17.

¶ Alſo no man ſhall take for threſſhynge of 〈◊〉 quarter of wheate or Rye, but .ii. d. ob. and fo • a quarter of Bayley or Dotes .i. d. ob. Alſo y • ſhall enquyre of thoſe that refuſe to ſerue in ••
mer, where they ſerued in wynter, & the ſtatu • therof is. Anno. 25. Ed. 3. Capi. 2.

☞ Alſo the lawe wyll,For ſeruantes in harueſte that yf any man ned • a ſeruaunte or labourer in harueſt ſeaſon tha • he maye come to the boroughe towne, and th • apprentices and theyr mayſters and the craft • men, without they be of reputacyon of hono • ſhalbe compelled to mowe, reape, and to do other laboures. Alſo they that haue vſed th • craft of huſbandry to the age of .xii. yere, ſha • nat go to no crafte afterwarde, for the cou •
naunt by them made is voyce, ſtatutum Ann •
12. R. 2. Capi. 5.

¶ Alſo yf any man requyre a ſeruant, and py •
fer wages,Wages atter the ſtatute. accordynge to the ſtatute, which wyll that the bayly of huſbandrye, ſhall ha •• xxiii. s. iiii. d. and veſture pryce .v. s. with mea • any drynke, a chyef hyne, carter, barger, and
ſheparde .rx. s̄. and veſture pryce foure. s̄. with meate and drynke, a commen ſeruante of huſbādre .xv. s̄ . and veſture pryce .iii. s. foure pens with meate and drynke, a woman .x. s. and veſtues pryce foure. s̄. with meate and drynke, a chylde of ye age of .xiiii. yere .vi. s̄. veſtute pryce thre ſhyllynge with meate and drynke. And yf any perſonne refuſe to ſerue or laboure, accordynge to the premyſſes, the Iuſtyces of Peace haue power to commyte them to warde, tyll they haue founde ſuertye to ſerue, as well by enquire, as by examynacion. Statutum. Anno. 23. H. 6. Cap. 13.

☞ Alſo yf any artifycer, laborer,Wages after the ſtatute. or ſeruaūt refuſs to ſerue accordynge to the ſtatute made in the .vii. yere of the reygne of kynge Henry ye eyght, whiche wyll that no bayly of huſbādry ſhal take for his wages by the yere aboue .xxvi s̄. viii. d. and tor his clothynge .v. s̄. with meate and drynke. No chyefe hyne, as a carter or a chyefe ſhepherde, aboue .xx. s̄. by the yere and▪ for his clothynge .v. s. with meate and drynke No comon ſeruant of huſbandrys aboue .xvi. s̄ eyghtpens by the yere, & for his clothings .iiii. s̄ with meate and drynke. No woman ſeruant aboue .x. s. by the yere, and for clothynge .iiii. s. with meate and drynke. No chylde within the age of .xiiii. yere aboue .vi. s̄. viii. d. by the yere and for his clothynge foure. s. with meate and drynke. And that none artifycer, nor labourer, hereafter named, take no more nor greatter wages than hereafter is lymyted, vpon payne feſſed as wel to the gyuer, as to the taker, that
is to ſaye, a free maſon, a mayſter carpenter, roughe maſon, brycklayer, a mayſter ryler, plō mer, glaſyer, heruer, nom ioyner, from Eaſter to Myghelmas euery of them ſyxe pens for the day, without meate and drynke, & with meate and drynke .iiii. pēs. And from Myghelmas to Eaſter .v. pens without meate and drynke, and with meate and drynke .iii. d. And the wages of ſhypwryghtes from the feaſt of Candeimas vnto the feaſt of ſaynt Myghel tharchaungel, ſhall n • t excede the forme enſuynge, that is to ſaye, the mayſter ſhyppecarpenter takynge the charge of the worke, hauyng mē vnder him by the day .v. d. with meate and drynke, and with out meate and drynke .vii. d Another ſhyppecarpenter, called an hewer by the day .iii. pens with meate and drynge, and without meate & drynke ſyxe pens An able clencher by the daye thre pens with meate and drynke, and without meate and drynke .v. pens. An holder by the day ii. pens with meate and drynke, and without meate and drynke iii. d. A mayſter talker by the day .iiii. pens with meate and drynke, and without meate and drynke fyue pens. Another meane kalker by the day .iii. d. with meate and drynke, and without meate and drynke .v. pens A calker labourynge by the • iyde, for as longe tyme as he maye labour aboue the water and byneth the water, ſhall nat excede for his wages for euery tyde .iii. d. with meate and drynk And from the feaſt of Myghelmas no Candeimas, the wages of a mayſter ſhyppewryght by the day ioure • ens with meate and drinke and
without meate and drynke .vi. d. An. hewer by the day .iii. d. with meate and drynke, & without meate and drinke .v. pens. An able clencher by the day two . d. ob. with meate and drynke, 〈◊〉 without meate and drynke .iiii. d. ob. An holdee by the day .i. d. ob. with meate and drynke and without meate and drynke cure. d. A mayſter kalker by the day thre pēs with meat and drynke, and without meate and drynke .v. pēs Another meane calker by the day two pens ob. with meate and drynke, and without meate 〈◊〉 drynke foure pens ob. And in ſhyres where mē vſe to gyue leſſe wages, there menne ſhal gyue leſſe wages. And the taker ſhalbe compelled to take accordynge as it is vſed. And the mayſter maſon and mayſter carpenter, whiche ſhal take the charge of the worke, hauynge vnder him .vi. men ſhal haue .vi. pens by the day with our meate and drynke, & with meate & drynke fyue pens. And that euery perſon and artyfycer aboue named, nat receyued in any worke be compelled to ſerue for the wag • s aboue reherſed. And that none artifycer reteyned in any ſeruyce to worke, departe tyll ſuche tyme as the worke be fynyſſhed, yf the perſon ſo reteynynge him, ſo longe wyll haue him and pay him his wages, vpon payne of impryſonment of any perſon ſo departynge by the ſpace of a moneth, & to make fyne of twentye ſhyllynges Alwayes forſene that yf the ſame artyfycer be deſyred to the Kynges ſeruyce or worke, than he may lawfully departe, ſo that he entee and be in the kynges ſeruyce and 〈…〉 And euery
other labourer or ortyfycer nat afore named, ſhall take from Eaſter tyll Myghelmas for euery day that he ſo laboureth except the ſeaſon of harueſt foure pens without meate & drynke and two pens with meate and drynke. And from Myghelmas tyll Eaſter thre pens without meate and drinke, and threhalfpens with meate and drynke. And in the ſayde tyme of harueſt, euery mower ſhall take by the day .iiii. pens with meate and drynke, & without meate or drynke ſyxe pens. A reper and a carter euery of them thre pens by the day with meat and drynke, and without meate and drinke .v. pens A woman labourer and other labourers euery of them two pens ob. by the day with meate & drynke, and without meate and drynke foure pens ob. And that no artifycer nor labourer workynge but halfe a day, take no wages but for halfe the day, and nothyng for the holy day And yf any baylyffe of huſbandrye, hyne, carter, or ſheparde, common ſeruant, woman ſeruaunt, or chylde ſeruant, aboue ſpecifyed nat reteyned in any ſeruyce or worke, refuſe to ſerue or worke, accordynge to the ordynaunce aforeſayde, than the ſayd perſonne to be commytted to warde, by the Conſtable or other head offycer within the cytie towne or village where the partye ſo refuſynge is, at the complaynte of hym that wyll receyue ſuche a ſeruaunt there to remayne tyl he haue founde ſuretye to ſerue accordynge to the ſayde ordynance. And yf any artifycer or labourer beynge nat retayned in • up ſeruice or worke, refuſe to
ſerue after the rate of his eſtate, or take more or greatter wages than is to hym afore lymytted, or take any wages for the holde day, where he worketh but halfe the day, than he ſhal forfayte for euery defaute, as often as he offendeth .xx. s. and he to be conuycted for euery ſuche defaulte, vp preſentment afore the Iuſtyces of the Peace in the ſeſſyons, accordynge to the common lawe, or by examynacyon of the Iuſtyces in the ſame ſeſſyons, or of two Iuſtices of the peace out of the ſeſſions, in any place within the ſhyre, wherin they be Iuſtices, and where ſuche defaultes ſhalbe made. The ſame forfayture of .xx. ſhyllīges to be leuied of theyr landes, goodes and catelles ſo offendynge. And euery artifycer and labourer muſt be at worke betwene the myddeſt of the moneth of March and the myddeſt of the moneth of September before .v. of the clocke in the mornynge. And he ſhall haue but halfe an houre at his breakfaſt and an houre and a halfe at hys dyner, at ſuche tyme as he hath ſeaſon to him appoynted for to ſleape. And at ſuche tymes as he hath no ſeaſon to him appoynted for to ſleape, than he ſhall haue but an houre at his dyner, and halfe an houre for his noone meate, and he ſhall nat departe from his worke durynge that ſeaſon tyll bewene ſeuen and eyght of the clocke in ye euenynge. And yf he offende in any of the ſayd articles, thā his defaute to be marked by him or his deputie, whiche ſhall paye his wages after the rate of the tyme that he hath offended. And from the myddeſt of Septembre,
to the myddes of Marche, euery artifycer and laborer muſt be at worke in the ſprynge of the day, and ſhall nat depart afore nyght. And that the ſayde artifycers and labourers ſhall nat ſleape by day, but onely frome the myddeſt of the monethe of Maye, vnto the myddeſt of the moneth of Auguſt. And yf any artyfycer or labourer make or cauſe any aſſemble or aſſaute, or hurt any perſon aſſygned to controll them, he ſhall then haue impryſoment by the ſpace of a yere, without le • tynge to bayle, or maynpryſe, and make fyne at the kynges wyll the ſame myſdemeanour to be tryed by examinacyon afore the Iuſtyces of peace. And from the ſayde ordynaunces there be no more excepted, but artyfycers and labourers within the cytie of London and lyberties of the ſame and alſo minours or labourers for tyme leade, yron ſyluer, and ſette coles, otherwyſe called ſmythes coles.Artifycers.

¶ Alſo there ſhall no labourer be reteyned by the weke, nor that no labourer, carpenter, tyler, plaſterer, dawber, nor couerer of houſes, take no wages for the holye dayes, nor for no feryalle, where they worke but to noone, but for the halfe daye, vpon paynt of forfayture to the kynge .xx. s̄. and the Stutute therof is. An 4. H. 4. Cap. 13

¶ Alſo no laborer for makynge of hey,Hey makers. ſhall take but a penye for the daye, and the mower v. d. for the acre, or fyue pence for his iourney, without meate and drinke, & the ſtatute therof is Anno. 25. Ed. 3. Cap. 1.

¶ Alſo no labourer reper in the fyrſt weke of Auguſt, ſhall take but .ii. d. a daye,wages in harueſte. the ſeconde daye .iii. d. and ſuche men ſhall brynge their inſtrumentes into market townes, to the intent that they ſhulde be hyred, and the ſtatute therof is An. 25. Ed. 3. Capi 1.

Tanners and • o • d way • ers¶ Alſo ye ſhall enguyre, yf any tanner vſe the crafte of cordewayner, or yf any cordewayner vſe the craft of a tanner, or yf they ſell exceſſyuely theyr ware. Vide ſtatutum. An. 13. R. 2. Capitulo decimoſecundo.

¶ Iuſtyces of peace in euery ſhyre within the •• mpties of theyr commiſſyons and auctorites haue power and auctorite to enquyre heare, & determyne euery offence here after to be done and commyted contrarye to the acte made for true tannynge and coryenge of lether, as well by informacion as by preſentment afore them and to make ſuche pro • es vpon euery preſentment, as they comonly do vpon Inditementes of treſpas. 24. H. 8. Cap. 1.

☞ Alſo yt ſhall enquyre of all them that ben Smythes that make arroweheades or quarel heades, yf they be well ſteled and braſed,Arowhed makers. and harde at the poynte, and eche of them haue a marke and token who made them, vpon payne to forfayte the ſame heades and quarels to the kynge, and ſhall be alſo impriſoned, and make a fyne at the kynges wyll. An. 7. H. 4. Capi. 7.
☞ Alſo of all clothemakers, that they make good and ſure clothe without curle or cockle, & that it kepe bredeth accordynge.

¶ Alſo that your vytaylours ſell holſome vytayleVytaylours.
for mannes bodye, and nat corrupte: and yf they ſell for exceſſe pryce, for the ſtatute wyll that they ſhall haue reſonable gayne, hauynge conſyderance of diſtance from the place from whence they fet it, The ſtatute therof is. An. 23. Ed. 3. Cap. 6.

¶ Alſo by the ſtatute of Rycharde, vytailers ſhall haue but reſonable gayne:Wytaylors by ſtatute. and they haue the contrarye, they ſhall be punyſſhed by the diſcrecion of the Iuſtyces of Peace. Alſo yf any bruer or baker demeane hym in any poynt contrarye to the ſtatute, called, Aſſiſa panis et ſeruicie) Alſo of Mayres, Baylyffes, ſhyryffes of Towneſhyppe, yf they haue putte and done their offyces of ſyttynge of the aſſyſe of breade and ale. &c.

¶ Alſo no hoſteler ſhall bake within him hys hors breade,Hoſtlers nor he ſhall take nought for lytter and ſhall haue to hys gayne an. ob. for euery buſſhell of Ootes, ouer the pryce in the markes Anno. 12. R. 2. Capi. 8. And that is conformed by the ſtatute made An. 4. H. 4. Capi. 24. whiche wyll that yf he bake his breade within him he ſhall yelde treble value of the breade ſo made in his hoſterye, and he ſhall forfayte the quadrell of the gayne that he hath ouer the halpe peny in the buſſhell of Ootes.

☞ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of all forſtallers.Forſtallers. A forſtaller is he that where any vitayle, or corne commeth to the market, lyeth in the waye and byeth it, to the entent to make the vytayle or corne in the markette dearer, in hurte and preiudice of the Kynges people, this vytayle and
corne yt is forſtalled, forfayted to the kynge: 〈◊〉 yf any of them haue ſolde it, ye ſhall enquyre of the value, that the Kynges may be aunſwered therof ſtatutum An. 15. E. 3. Cap. 3.

☞ Alſo yf there be any that byeth or ſelleth more wolle to the ſacke that .xxvi. ſtoone,Sackes of wolle and more to the • toone then .xiiii. pounde, the marchaundyſe ſo bought, is forfayte to the kynge and the ſtatute therof is. An. 14. E. 3. Cap. vlt
er .Regratours.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre of al regratours. A regratour is he that whan the vytayle or Corne is brought to the market, byeth it at his owne pryce, and ſelleth it agayne in the markette at a more derer pryce, in hurte and preiudice of ye people, the ſayde thinge ſo regrated is forfaite and yf he haue ſolde it, the value therof is forfayte. &c.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre yf any man bye or ſell by poyſe of auncell,Meſure •
whiche is forbyden by dyuers Statutes, for the deceyte that hath ben founde therin, vpon payue of forfayture of the goodes ſo payſed. And the ſtatute therof is Anno. 8. H. 6. Cap. 5.

¶ Alſo of them that bye by the buſſhell, pecke galone, potell, or quart, or any other meaſure,Meſures after the ſtanderds without it be enſealed, accordynge to the ſtandarde of the Eſcheker: and ſuche as be founde gyltye herein, ſhalbe committed to the ſhyryffes whiche ſhall reteyne them in pryſon, tyll they haue made fyne to the Kynge, the ſtatute therof is. An. 14. Ed. 3. Capi. 12.

¶ Alſo ye ſhall enquyre yf euery Cytie borow and towne of the realme of Englande,weyght. haue a
comon balance. with comon weyghtes ſealed accordynge to the ſtandarde of the Eſcheker▪ vpon the comon coſtes of the ſayd cyte borow or towne, in the kepynge of the Mayre or conſtable of the ſame, with whiche balance and common weyght all the inhabytauntes of the ſame cytie boroughe or towne may freely wey without any thynge payenge, & that they thus haue on payne to forfayte euery cytte .x. li. euery boroughe an C. ℥. euery towne where a conſtable is .rl.s. the ſtatut therof is. Anno. octau • Henrici ſexti Cap. 5.

¶ Alſo of them that vſe double meaſures,Meſures as to bye be a great and to ſell by a ſmall, in dyſceyte of the Kynges people, for it is ordeyned that one weyght, one meaſure, and one yarde be thorough all the lande. And he that doth treſpas agaynſt this ordynaunce, ſhall haue a yeres impryſonment, and be raunſomed at the kynges wyll. Statutum inde. Anno. 27. Eo. 3. Capitulo. 10.

☞ Alſo that no mā bye wolle by the wordes (good packynge) or by other wordes lyke,wole packynge. vppon payne that is to ſay, the broker to haue enpryſonment of halfe a yere, & the byer to make fyne after the quaniytie of the treſpas to the kynge, and the partie that fynteth him gr • ued by the ſayde bargayne, ſhal haue double damages of that he hath ſuffered by the ſayde occaſyen. The ſtatute therof is Anno decimotertiv Richardi ſecundi Capi. 9.

¶ Alſo yf watche be kepte in euery towne accordinge to the ſtatut of wyncheſter,watch to be kepe. the which
wyll, that they ſhall be kepte from the Aſſeneſyon vnto Myghelmas, and that euery Cytye ſhall haue ſyxe men, euery boroughe and ports two men, and euery other Towne ſyre men in the hoole, and they ſhall watche from ſonne to ſoune, and yf there come any ſtraunger by thē, they haue power to arreſt him, tyl the morowe and yf they fynde hym of good name and fame they maye lette hym goo. Vide Staturum Wyncheſt.

☞ Alſo that euery man ſhal haue arraye accordyng to his degre,Iran • in defēce of ye realm •
in the defence of the Realme, and that euery man betwene .xl. and .xv. ſhalbe ſworne to haue competent atr • ye with in him, that is to ſaye, a man of .xl. li. lyuelode and goodes to the value of .rl marke, an habergyn, ſalet, ſpeare, ſwerde, and hors. A man of .x. li lande, and goodes to the value of .xr. marke, and habergyn, ſale • , ſpeare, ſwearde.

¶ And a mā of and C. s̄. of lāde, a ſpeare, vow arrowes, and ſwearde: A man of .xl s of lande and aboue two. C. s̄. of lande, bowe, arrowes, ſoeare and ſworde, A man vnder the value of .rl. s. of landes, and goodes, vnder the value of .xr. markes, gyſermes and other ſmalle weayons. And they without the foreſt, bowes and arrowes. And they within the foreſt, bowes and pelle • tes. The ſtatute therof is wyncheſter Cap. vl.

Agaynſt puru • yours.☞ Alſo that no putueyour, nor other man, by more corne to the quarter than eyght buſſhelles by the borde, vpon payne of impryſonement of a yer • , and to forſayte an C. s. to the
kynge, and an .C. s. to the partye, and that as often as any of them be therof atteynted, and the ſtatute therof is. An. 1. H. 5. Cap. vlt
er .

¶ Alſo of them that ſurmyt them ſelfe to be ye kynges takers or purueyours,Surmitting purueyours. & haue no wrytynge vnder the Kynges ſeale, prouynge the ſome, for the lawe wyll no man ſhalbe the Kynges taker or purueyour, but yf he haue wrytynge vnder the kynges ſeale, & the wrytynge ſhal make mencion what thynge he ſhal take, & who that doth the contrary, is a Felon ſtatutū Anno. 25. Ed. 3. Capi. 1.

¶ Alſo yf any taker,Bieng of ſhep •
purueyour, or byet take mo ſhepe, before ye tyme of ſheryng, but as may reſonably ſuffyce tyll the tyme of ſherynge, not after that tyme, but as many ſhepe ſhorne, as may reſonably ſuffyce thē for the tyme to come & be therof atteyted, at the ſuyt of the kyng or of the party, it ſhalbe done of him as of a thei • or a robber, the ſtatute is an. 25. E. 3. Capi. 15.
¶ Alſo if any purueyour ſurmit that he byeth it to the Kynges vſe, and after tourneth it to his owne vſe, it is felonye, the ſtatute therof i • An. 36. E. 3. Capi. 3.

¶ Alſo that no purueyour ſhall ſet pryce hym ſelfe, but the bayly or cōſtable with .iiii. honeſt men with them, ſhall ſette the pryce, and yf be do contrarye, it is ſelony, the ſtatute therof is An. 5. Ed. 3. Capi. 2.

¶ Alſo yf any purueyour, or taker, take any thynge of the ſomme of .xl. s. or vnder, and paynat in hande, the ſtatute wyll that he ſhal loſe his offyce, and paꝑe as muche to the party gr •
ued,
as commeth to the value of the thynge ſo takē, & the ſtatute therof is An. 2. H. 4. Ca. 14.

☞ Alſo of al thoſe that gyueth any lyueryes to any other men than to his maynyall ſeruantes and learned counſel of the one lawe and of the other.Lyuetye. But by equyte of the ſame a bayly 〈◊〉 a receyuont be excepte, the partie that gyuethe lyueryes ſhal forfayte an. C. s.
〈◊〉 the taker .xl. s. and he that wyll ſue ſhall haue the one halte of the forfayture, the ſtatute therof is An. octauo Henrici ſerti Cap. quarto.

¶ Alſo of them that hauke or hunte in other mennes warrannes,Hunder •
and take theyr conyes, feſaunce or patriches. Alſo that no artifyces labourer or other lay man, whiche hath nat lā des or tenementes to the value of tortye ſhyllynges by yere, Preeſt or other clerke, whiche is nat aduaunced to the value of .x. li. by yere, ſhal haue or kepe f • ō henſforth any grayhoūde hounde, or other dogge for to hunte, or fyrettes, heyes, nettes, harepypes, cordes, or other ingyns, to take or dyſtroye deare, hares, or conyes, or other gentylmennes game, on payne of one yeres impryſonment, the ſtatute therof is An. 13. R. 2. Cap. 13.

☞ Alſo of them that hunte by nyght,Hūtynge by upght. or with viſers, or with taces paynted, or otherwyſe diſguyſed, to the intenis that they wolde nat be knowen, and yf they counſel the ſayd huntyng or any perſone that was with them defectyus it is felonye, and yf the ſayde hunters confeſſe the trouth, it is but treſpas agaynſt the kynge and fynable. An. 1.1. H. 7. Cap. 7.

¶ Alſo yf any perſon, that hath no parke 〈◊〉 his owne, kepe or cauſe to be kepte any dea •• hayce or • uckeſtalles, the payne is, to forfay ••
〈◊〉
li. for euery moneth. And no perſon ſha •• ſtalke, or cauſe any other to ſtalke, with a ••• buſſhe or dea • to any deare, without lycen •• of the owner, may • er of the game, or kepet • exc p • e •• be in his owne grounde, vpon payn • of .r. li. and euery perſonne m • ye ſewe for th ••• ſayd forfayture by action of De •• e, wherin 〈◊〉 wager of lawe, effoyne, nor protection ſhal ly •
▪ And Iu • ices of peace haue power to exami •• the premyſſes, and the partyes founde in defaulte to commytte to pryſonne, • yll they hau • founde ſuretye • to paye t • e ſay • e forfaytes▪ And thoſe Ju •• yces to haue the .x. parte of th • forfayture for theyr laboure. Anno. 19. Henri •• teptinu Capi 11.

☞ Alſo yf any perſon or perſones, of wh ••• eſtate,Fynding of nowk •• . degre, or condycyon they be, trace, dy •
ſirope, or kyll any hate in the ſnowe, wt dogg •• bytche, or otherwyſe, the fyne for euery ſuch • hare ſo ky • l • o, is ſyxe. s. eyght pens. Anno. 14. et. 15. H. 8. Capi. 10.

¶ Alſo yf any perſone fynde any faucon th •• is loſt, terceiet, laner, or lanerette, or any oth •• hawke, mayntenaunce he ſhall brynge hym 〈◊〉 the Shyryffe whiche ſhall make proclamacyon in all the good townes of the Shyre, th •• he hath ſuche a hawke in kepynge. And y •• the • orde whiche hath lo •• e hym, or any of hy • many can prone t • at it is • i • forde • , lette hy • paye for his •••• tes, and qua • the hauke. St •
tutum
anno. 37. Edwardi teriii Capi. vitimo.

To examyne the ſhyriffe & his clerks¶ Alſo the (Cuſtos Rotulorum) hathe power • o aſſygne two Iuſlyces of the peace at the generall ſeſſyons to examyne the ſhyryffe and his clerkes for myſſe entrynge of the playntes had before hym ſelfe in his turne, and alſo for makynge of his ſtreetes, as it appereth by the ſ • ature made Anno. 11. H. 7.

¶ Alſo yf any playnt be entred in the countyt but yf the pleyntyffe be in the court in propre perſon, or by attourney,Entryng of playn • in the court. well knowen and of good fome, and that the playntyffe ſhall fynde pledges, men well knowen in the countrye, and that the playntif ſhall haue but one playne • or one Treſpas or contracte, and that the ſhy • yffe ſhall nat entre any playnte, but ſuche as • he playntyfe doth ſuppoſe, that be hath cauſe of acceyon for. And yf the ſhyryffe, vnderſhyryffe, or ſhyre clerke, entre any playnte agaynſt • he ordynaunces, he ſhall loſe .xl. s. the one half • o the kynge, and the other halfe to hym that wyll ſue for the ſame by accyon of Dette, or in • ormacyon in the eſcheker. And yf there be any defaute in the Baylyffes of the hundredes, in warnynge of the defendauntes, to appere and • nſwere to the playntes commenced agaynſte • hem, the ſayde Baylyffes, ſhall forfayte for • uery defaulte vnto out ſoueraygne Lorde the • ynge .xl. s. the ſtatute therof is. Anno. 11. H. 7. Capitulo decimoquinto.

Shoting in longs bowes.☞ It • m▪ whether the kynges ſubiectes, nat • ame, nor hauynge no lawful impediment, and • eynge within the age of fortye, ye • es, • xcepte
ſpirituall men, Iuſtytes. &c. and barons of 〈◊〉 Eſcheker, vſe ſhotynge in longe bowes, & ha •• a bowe cōtinually in his houſe, to vſe hym ſe •• And that fathers and gouernours of chyldr •• teache them to ſhote, and that bowes and a •• towes be bought for chyldren vnder, xvii. a •• aboue .vii. yere by him that hath ſuch a chyld •• in his houſe, and the Mayſter maye ſtopp •• agayne of his wages, and after that age he 〈◊〉 prouyde them him ſelfe, and who that is foū
•• in defaulte, nat hauynge bowes and arrow •• by the ſpace of a monethe, to forfayte twel •
pens. And bowyers for euery bowe of e ••• to make two of elme, whiche, or other wode 〈◊〉 meane pryce, and yf they be founde to doo 〈◊〉 contrarye, to be commytted to warde, by th • ſpace of .viii. dayes or more. And that butt •• be made in euery cytie, towne, and place, acco •
dynge to the lawe of auncyent tyme vſed, a •• the inhabytauntes and dwellers in euerye 〈◊〉 them, to excercyſe them felfe with long bow • in ſhotynge at the ſame, and els where on h •
lye dayes and other tymes conuenyent. A •• that al bowſtaues of ewe be open and nat ſo •• in bundels, nor clofe. And that no ſtranger, nat beynge denyſen, ſhal nat connye out 〈◊〉 the kynges obey ſaunce any bowes, arrow •• or ſhaftes, without the kynges ſpecyall lyce •• vpon payns of forfayture, and alſo impryſo •
ment, nor vſe ſhotynge in a longe bowe, wit •
out the kynges lycence, vpon payne to forfay •• the bowes and atrowes to the kynges ſu ••
cies that wyll ſeaſe them. The ſtatute the ••
is Anno ſexo Henrici occaui Capitulo ſecundo

¶ Item yf any perſon ſhote in any croſ • owe, or handgonne, but he or other to his vſe,Shoting in croſſe bowe or hādgone. or to the vſe of his wyte haue thre C. marke lande yerely, vpon payne of forfayture therof, and x. li. for euery tyme ſo offendynge, halfe to the kynge, and halfe to hym that wyll ſue, and euery of the Kynges ſubiec • may ſeale the ſayd croſbowes and handgonnes to his owne vſe And that no man kepe any croſbowe or handgonne in his houſe, or • ls where, vpon payne of impryſonment, and to forfayte. x. li. to the Kynge, excepte he haue landes as aboue, and accepte makers of Croſbowes, whiche maye kepe them to ſell, and ſhore in them for aſſaye and excepte them that dwell within .vi. myles of the ſee coſtes, or in the Englyſ • he merches neare Scotlande, whiche maye kep them for defence of theyr houſe and goodes, and alſo theyr ſhyppes. And except marchauntes that haue them to ſell. Anno. 15. H. 8. Cap. 7.

¶ Alſo of all offences commytted or done contrarye to the forme of the eſtatute concernynge ſhotynge in Croſbowes and handgonnes, for whiche the fyne is no leſſe than ten. li. to be aſſeſſed vpon euery preſentment and conuyceyon, accordynge to the due courſe of the lawe. The ſame Fyne to be payde and leuyed onely to the kynges vſe. And Iuſtyce of Peace vpon a due examynacyon and profe before hym hadde or made by his diſcrecion, hath tull power and auctorytye to ſende or commytre the offender or offenders, to hym, conueyed an •
brought by any perſon or perſons, to the nexet Goale, there to remayne tyll the forfayture ſhalbe truely contented and payde by the ſayde offender. The one moyte of the ſame penaltye to be payde to the kynges hyghnes, and ye other moyte to the fyrſte brynger or conueyour of the ſayde offendour to the ſame Iuſtyce of peace. Anno. 25. H. 8. Capi. 17.

☞ Item yf the Coroner vpon requeſt to him made to come and enquyre vpon the vyewe of any perſonne ſlayne,Coroner. drowned, or otherwyſe deade by myſaduenture, do nat dylygently his offyce vpon the viewe of the ſayd body of euery ſuche perſon or perſons, without any thyng therfore: the payne to euery coroner, that wyll nat endeuer hym ſelfe to do his offyce (as is aforeſayde, or takynge any thynge for the doynge of his office is. xl. s. for euery tyme. An. 1. H. 8. Cap. 7.

¶ Item that no playne clothe, tacked, nor folded,Playne clothe. ſhall be put to ſale in the ſhyres of Somercet, Dorcet, or Glouceſter, but that they be opened, vpon payne to forfayte them, ſo that ſhe byers may ſe them and knowe them, as it is vſed in the countye of Eſſex, and that the makers, weauers, and fullers putte theyr markes to euery clothe that they ſhall worke. An. 13. R. 2. Cap. 11.

☞ Item that clothe makers ſhall nat make theyr clothes myxte with lams wolle,Cloth makers. flockes, or corke, vpon payne to forfayte .xx. s. for euerye clothe or halfe cloche made to the contrary, the one halfe to the kynge the other to hym
that wyll ſeyſe it. Except that one may make it of lammes wolle by it ſelfe, without myxyng with any other wolle. Except alſo that corke maye be vſed in dyenge vpon woded wolle, and alſo in dyenge of all ſuche clothe, that is onely made of woded wolle, ſo that the ſame wolle and clothe be perfectely boyled and madered. And the fuller ſhall occupye tayſels and nat cardes. An. 4. Ed 4. Cap. 1.

☞ Item no Eſchetour be choſē, except he or other to hys vſe at the tyme that he is choſen,Eſchetor may diſpende dy yere in the ſame countye .xx. li. in Fee, Fee tayle, or for terme of lyfe. And he may nat let his offyce to ferme, nor make a deputie, yf it be nat ſuch one for whom he wyll anſwere, and he muſt gyue knowledge of the deputacyon to the Treaſorer & Barons of the Eſcheker within .xx. dayes after. If the eſchetour do otherwyſe than is lymytted here, he and his deputye, that ſo wyll occupye vnder hym, nat hauynge landes vt ſupra, or nat makynge ſuche certifycat, ſhall forfayte .xl. li. the one halfe to the Kynge, and the other to hym that wyll ſue by accion of Dette, wherin no eſſoyne, proteccyon, nor wager of lawe ſhall lye. Anno. 12. E. 3. Cap. 9.

Takinge of Herōs¶ Item yf any perſon ſlee or take, or cauſe to be taken, but in his owne grounde, by meane crafte or ingyn, but with hawkynge or with longe bowe, any Herons, vpon payne to forfayte for euery Heron ſo ſlayne or taken .vi. s̄. viii. d. nor take any yonge Herons out of the neſte, withoute lycence of the owner of the
grounde vpon payne to forfayte for euery Heron ſo taken out of the neſte x s̄. And he that wyll, may ſue for it by accyon of Dette. And .ii. Iuſtyces of the peace at their ſeſſyons may examyne ſuche offender, and yf he be foūde in defaulte to commyt hym to pryſon, tyll he haue founde ſuretie for the payment of the ſame for fayture to the kynge, and the Iuſtyces ſo examynynge to haue the .x. parte for theyr labours Anno. 19. H. 7. Cap 11.

☞ Item that none gylde ſhethes, nor mettall but ſyluer,Gyldyng of ſhethes a mettal. and the ornamentes of the churche and ſpurres for knyghtes, and all the apparayle that longeth to a Baron and aboue that eſtate, vpon payne of forfayture to the Kynge ten tymes as muche as the thynge that is gylded is in value, and ſhall haue a yetes impryſonement, and he that wyll ſue for the Kynge ſhall haue the thyrde parte. Anno. 8. Henrici. 5. Capitulo. vitimo.
¶ Item yf the weares of ryuers be of reaſonable bygneſſe and nat to ſtrayte, ſo that the frye of fyſſhed be nat dyſtroyed.Weares. Anno. 17. Ri. 2 Capitulo nono.

¶ Item yf any denyſen bye wolles but of the owners of the ſhepe, except in the ſtape, or regrate wolles or other marchaundyſe of the ſtaple,Bying of wolles. vpon payne of forfayture of the thynge ••
grated. Anno. 14. R. 2. Capi. 4.

¶ Item yf any cary marchaūdyſe of ye ſtaple to any other place than to Calyce without lycence ſhalbe punyſſhed as a felon, excepte wolles that paſſe the ſt • aytes of Marocke, the ſtatute
therof is Anno decimo octauo H. 6. Ca. 15
¶ Alſo yf any bye wollen yarne that wyll nat make clothe therof. 8. H. 6. Cap. 5.

☞ Alſo of brewers that ſell ale or bye other wyſe than occordynge to the pryce rated and ſet by the Iuſtyces of peace out of Cytie and townes corporate,Brewes. the payne is to forfayte of euery barrell ſyxe. s̄. for euery kylderkin thre. s̄. iiii. d. and for euery fyrkyn ii. s̄. and for euery veſſe • l conteynynge greatter nombre or galons x. s̄. Anno. 23. H. 8. Cap 4.
Sellers of wyne.¶ Item of them that ſhal attempt to ſell any wynes in groſſe or by retayle, contrarye to the acte therof made God. An. Cap. 7.

Sellyng of horſes to ſcoryſmen.¶ Alſo of felonyes commytted in ſellynge, exchaungynge, or delyuerynge of any horſe, geldynge, or meare, without the Kynges lycence, to the vſe of any Scotyſſheman, contraye to the acte therof made eod An. Cap. 16.

Sowing of flare 〈◊〉 hempe.¶ Alſo of them that ſowe nat yerely one xoode with flare ſeede. or hempſede, for euery forty acres, whiche he or they ſhal happen to haue in occupacyon, without fraude or couyne, on payne to forfaite .iii. s̄. iiiii. d. for euery .xl. acres whiche any perſone ſhall haue in occupacyon Anno. 14. H. 8. Cap. 3.
¶ Alſo of them that kyll waynelynges contrarye to the acte therof made An. 24. H. 8. Ca. 9.

Killing of choughs crowes 〈◊〉 tookes.¶ Alſo of them that offende agaynſte the ſtatute made to dyſtroye choughes, crowes, and tookes, and of fermours and other that do nat accordynge to the ſame acte, eodem Anno. Capitulo decimo.

¶ Alſo of ſuche as commytte offences.Apparel. and 〈◊〉 forfayte contrarye to the ſtatute, made for r •
formacyon of exceſſe in apparell, eodem Anno. Capitulo decimotertio.
Frye of fyſſhe.¶ Alſo of ſuche as offende contrarie to ye effecte of an acte made agaynſt kyllynge of yong ſpaume or frye of E • les or ſalmon. Anno. 15. H. 8. Capi 7.
Wylde foule.¶ Alſo of them that offende agaynſte the acte made to auoyde diſtruccyon of wylde foule, eodem. Anno. Capi. vndecimo.
Nombre of ſhepe.¶ Alſo of them that offende agaynſt the acte lymyttynge what nombre of ſhepe menne ſhall kepe, occupye, and haue in theyr poſſyſſyon at on tyme. eod. An. Cap. 13.

For ertinguyſhing of the byſhoppe of Rome.¶ Item of al offences, contemptes, and tranſgreſſyons commytted and done contrarye is the acte made to extynguyſſhe the auctorytie of the byſſhop of Rome, for they that offende ſhal incurre and ronne into the daungers, penaltyes, paynes, and forfaytures, ordeyned and prouyded by the ſtatute of prouiſyon and Premunire, made in the ſyxtene yere of kynge Rycharde the ſeconde a gaynſt ſuche as attempte ꝓcure, or make prouiſyon to the ſee of Rome, or els where, for any thynge, to the derogacyon, or contrarye to the prerogatyue royall, or iuriſdiccion of the crowne and dignite of thy • realme. And the Iuſtyces of the peace ſhall certifye euery preſentment afore them hadde o • made, hefore the Kynge in hys benche, with •• xl. dayes nexte after any ſuche preſentment • had or made, yf the terme be then open, yf nat
than the fyrſte daye of the terme nexte folowynge the ſayde .xl. dayes, vpon payne that euery Iuſtyce of aſſyſe or peace, before whom ſuche preſentmēt ſhalbe made, makynge defaute of ſuche certifycat, ſhal loſe and forfayte forty poūde to the Kynges hyghnes. Anno. viſecimo octauo Henrici octaui Capi. 10.

¶ Alſo of them that ſel wynes aboue ye pryce • ymytted by the Statute, that is Gaſkoyne.Wynes. Guyon, or Frenche wynes aboue .viii. pens ye galon, that is to ſaye, a peny the pynte .ii. pens • he quart, foure pens the pottell, and .viii pēs the galon, ye forfayture is for euery pynte ſolde aboue the ſayde pryce foure. d. for euery quart • yght pens, for euery pottell twelue pens and for euery galon ſo ſolde aboue the ſayde pryce two ſhyllynges. And that no malmeſeys rom
•• ys, ſackes, nor other ſwete wynes ſhall be • olde by retayle aboue .xii. pens the galon .vi. d.
• he pottell .iii. d. the quart, and .i. d. ob. the pynt • pon payne to loſe and forfayte .iii. s̄. iiii. d. for • uery galon .xx. d. for euery pottell .xii. d. for eue
• y quart .vi. d. and for euery pynte, that ſhalbe • olde contrarye to thys acte. Anno. 28. Henrici • ctaui Capitulo decimoquarto.

¶ And Iuſtyces of the peace, within the pre
•• nctes and lymyttes of theyr offices, at the de
•• re & requeſt of any of the Kynges ſubiectes, 〈◊〉 whom denyer of ſale of wynes is made, may •• tre into the houſes, ſellers, and other places • here wynes ſhall lye or be, and ſell and dely
•• the ſame wynes, deſyred to be bought to 〈◊〉 perſonne or perſonnes, requyrynge or deſyrynge
to bye the ſame, offrynge full payment for the ſame without delaye, after the rate of the pryces therof nowe beynge ſette, or hereafter to be ſette by the Lordes & Iuſtyces accordynge to the acte therof made. Anno viſecimo quarto Henrici octaui Cap. 6.

For fythea.¶ Two Iuſtyces of the peace, wherof one to be of the Quorum, haue power and auctorytye, vpon informacyon and requeſte to them made by the ordynarye, his cōmyſſarye or offycyall, to attache or cauſe to he attached ſuch • perſone or perſons, as wyll nat be ordred accordyng to the act made for tythes to be payde throughe the realme, and the ſame perſone to commytte to warde, there to remayne without bayle or maynpryſe, tyll he haue founde ſuffycient ſuertye, to be boūde by recogniſance or otherwyſe to the kynges vſe, to gyue dew • obedyence to the proceſſe procedynge decres, 〈◊〉 ſentences of the Eccleſyaſtycall court of thy • realme, wherin ſuche ſuyte ſhall depende. And the ſayde two Iuſtyces haue power to take, ••
ceyue, and recorde recognyſance, and oblyg •
cions in the cauſe aboue. Anno viſecimo ſeptimo Henrici octaui Cap. 20.

Haukes egges.¶ Alſo yf any perſon take or cauſe to be taken the egges out of the neſte of any Faucum Goſhauke, Laner, or Swāne, the payne is impryſonment of a yere and a daye, and to ma •• fyne to the Kynges wyll. The ſtatute thero • is. Anno vndecimo Henrici ſeptimi. Capitu •• decimo ſeptimo.

div.head: PLacita coram A B. et ſociis ſuis cuſtodiendis pacis dn̄i Regis, ac iuſtitiariis ſuis ad diuerſa felonia tranſgreſſa et alia malefacta in Comitatu Mid, audiēda et terminanda aſſignad apud Weſtmonaſtetium tali die. &c. Anno regni regis. &c.
div.p:
prec. fac • ꝑ Iuſtic. pacis vic̄ direct
er proſom̄ ſeſſ.☞ A B. et ſocit ſui, cuſtodes pacis Domini Regis in Comitatu Mid audienda et terminanda aſſignatis, vic. M. ſalutem. Ex parte dn̄i regis tibi precipimus, ꝙ non omit
er prop
• er aliquam libertatē in baliua tua, quin eā ingrediaris & venire fac. corā nobis tali die proximo futuro apud W. xxiiii. liberos et legales homines de quolibet Hundredo. Trithingo, et Wapentagio, ac de quolibet burgo de balliua tua predicta, ad faciendum ibidem, que ſibi ex parte dn̄i Regis iniungent
ur . Seire fac. etiā omnibus ſeneſcallis, conſtabular̄ ſubconſtabular̄ et balliuis infra hundred et burgū predictum, qd tunc ſint ibi, habentes ſecum omnia nomina artificum laboratorum et ſeruientium infra eorum balliuas, exc • ſſiue contra formam ordinacionum & ſtatutorum capientium, ſufficient
er imbreuiatorum. Proclamare inſuper facias, quod omnes illi, qui tam pro domino rege
quam pro ſe ipſis verſus ipſos artifices lobatatores et ſeruientes, aliqus querelas, iuxta formam ordinationum et ſtatutoruum predcto tum cōqueri vel proſequi voluerint, quod tunc ſint ibidem coram iuſticiar • is inde proſecuturi Et tu ipſe tunc ſis ibidem, tum balliuis hundred
libertatum at burgorum predictorum, habens tecum omnia nomine ſeneſcallorum, conſlabulariorū, et ſubcōſtabul. Intratorum, & hoc preceptū. Te predict
er I B. apud W. t • u die &c

¶ Et cū ad diem illum vic. returneuerii preceptum predictum c • ram prodic • is Iuſticiatiis tunc vocent
er iurato • es, et pet toe captatur inquiſicio, et ſimiliter capientur pr • ſentationes de fingulis Conſtabulariis, et fubcon •• adulatiis per ſe, de exceſſ •• ue ar •• ſicum laboratotum et ſeruientium. Et quelibet preſentatio eorum cam̄ vale • per ſe, quantum preſ • ntatie per. xii. capt
er in hac ꝑte de exceſſibꝰ • redietis. &c

Proceſſ ſuper indictemen tum.¶ Preceptum eſt vic quod non omitta • propter aliquam libertatem in balliua ſua, quin venire fac, coram A B. et fociis ſuis cuſtodidus pacis domini Regis, ac Iuſtic. ad diu • rſa felon̄ tranſgreſſ. et malefact
er in com̄ predicto audiend et termmandum aſſign̄ apud w. tali die proximo futuro. C D E. et F. ad reſpondend. domino regi ſuper diuerſis arriculis ſuper ipſos preſentatis, et habeat tbi tune hoc preceptum. Teſtes. A B. apud M. tali die et anno. &c.

¶ Preceptum fuit vic. quod non omiit
er propter aliquam libertatem. &c quin venire • ac, coram A B. et ſociis ſuis,Venit
ur fa
• iasſuꝑ indictat
er
cu •• od pacis domini Regis or Iuſtre. ſuis ad diuerſa felon̄, tranſgr̄, et alia malefact
er in com̄ predicto audienda et terminanda aſſign̄ apud W. ad hunc diē C. D E. et F. ad reſpōdenū dn̄o regi be d • uerſi • articulis ſuper ipſos preſentat
er , et ipſi non vener̄. Et precep • um tuit vic. quod non omittat &c. quin veu • t • faceret eos. &c. et vic. returnauit,
quod predicti C D. E et F attachiati ſunt per & 〈◊〉 &c. ideo ipſi in miſericordia. Et preceptu • eſt vic. quod non omit
er . &c. quin eos dillcingat. &c. per omnes cerras. &c. Et ꝙ de exitibus eorum &c. Et ꝙ habeas corpora eorum. &c. coram prefat
er Iu • ic apuo ro taii d • e proximo • uturo Et d •
p̄oict
er C et F. vic returnauit
er quod • pſi nihil ha • ent. &c. per quod. &c. Ideo preceptum eſt vic. &c. quod no • omitt
er . &c. quia captat eos, ſi. &c Et eos ſaluo. &c. Ita ꝙ habeat corpora eorum ao prefato; locum et diem, ad reſpondendn̄ dn̄i regi de diuerſis articulis ſuper ipſos preſentatis. &c.

¶ Preceptum eſt vic.Diſtē. et capias. quod non omitt
er propter aliquam libertatē in balliua ſua, quin diſ • r̄ E. et F per omnes terras. &c. et quod de exitibus. &c. et quod habeat corpora corum coram A B. et ſo • us ſuis, cuſtodus pacis dn̄i regis et Iuſtic. ſuis ad diuerſa felon̄, tranſgr̄, et aua malefact
er in com̄ predict
ur , audiendu et terminā dum aſſign̄ apud w • t • li die prori. futur̄, ad reſpondendū ro nino regi ſuper diuerſis articulis ſuper ipſos preſentatis. Precept
er eſt etiam, ꝙ non omitt
er &c. quin cap̄ C. et D et eos ſaluo cuſtodi, et quod habeat eorpora eorum corā prefatis Iuſtic. ad prefat
er diem et locum, ad reſpondendum dn̄o regi ſuper diuerſis articulis ſuper ipſos preſentat
er . Et habeas ibi hoc preceptum. Teſt. A B. &c. Nota bene, quod in eadem forma fiant proceſſus ſicut alias, et ſicut pluries, ſi neceſſe fuerit.

¶ Preceptum eſt vic. ſicut plur̄,Plut
ur . ꝙ non omitteret. &c. quin caperet. &c. C. et 〈◊〉 . ſi. &c. ſaluo
&c. Ita ꝙ haberet corpora eorū coram A B. et ſociis ſuis cuſtodibus pacis domini Regis, et iuſtic. ſuis. &c. apud W. &c. tali die. &c. proxi. futuro, ad reſpondendum domino regi de diuerſis articulis ſuper ipſos preſentatis, et ipſi non venire. Et vic. modo mandat, quod non ſunt in uēti &c. Ideo preceptum eſt vic. qd exigi facias eos de com̄ in com̄, quouſ
que &c. vtiagent
ur , ſi nō cōpatuerint. &c. Et ſi. &c. tunc eos capiat, et 〈◊〉 of ſaluo. &c. Ita quod habeat corpora eoru • coram pretat
er Iuſtic. apud W. tali die, ad reſpondend domino regi de diuerſis articulis ſuper ipſos preſentatis, et vnde vic. return̄ tall die ꝙ predicti C. et D non fuerunt inuenti. &c.

¶ Henricus dei gracia, Rex Anglie Francie, et Hibernie fidei defenſor,Exigi facias. vic. Midelſex ſalutem. Precipimus tibi, quod exigi • acias C. et D. de com̄ in com̄, quoſ
que ſecundum lege • et couſuetudinem regni noſtri Anglie vtlagen • ſi non comparuerint, et ſi comparuerint, tum eos capias, et ſaluo cuſtod facias, ita quod babeas corpora eorum coram A. B. et ſociis ſuis cuſtodi pacis noſtre, ac Iuſticiariis nr̄is ad diuerſas felon̄. &c. in com̄ tuo audiend et terminand aſſign̄ apud w. tali die ad reſpondēd •
̄ nobis de diuerſis feloniis et tranſgr̄, vnde i •
dictati ſunt. Et vnde tu ipſe mandaſti cora • prefatis Iuſticiariis nr̄is tali die, ꝙ predict • C. et D. non ſunt inuenti in Balliua tua. E • habeas ibi hoc breue. Teſte. A. B. apud, &c. Anregni noſtri viceſimo.

¶ Et nota ꝙ conſimilis proceſſus fiat in omnibus articu •• s preſentatis, ſuper quos pſoceſſus
eſt veniire facias, alias, capias, plur̄ capias, et erigi facias. &c.

Venit
ur facias de cō temptis.¶ Prec. e • t vic. ꝙ non omitiat, quin venire faccoram A B et ſociis ſuis. &c. vt ſ. apud W. tali die, ad reſpondendum domino Regi de quibuſdam contēptibus tranſgr̄ et exceſſibus cō tra formam ſtatuti fact
er . Et habeas. &c. vt ſupra. Et ſur ceo quod capias, et exigi fac̄. vt. s.

¶ Et nota quod proceſſus verſus operarios. artifices, ei ſeruientes eſt per ſtatutum, venite facias, capias et exigi facias. Item verſus magiſtros, venire facias capias, alias capias plur̄ capias, exigi facias.
¶ Nota quod proceſſus de feloniis eſt capias capias alias, et exigi facias.

¶ Nota quod quolibet breue de cap̄ de felomis ſemper habet ſpacium trium ſeptimanatum inde dat
er vſ
que ad reſpond. eiuſdem

¶ Rex vic. ſal Prec. tibi. qd nō omitt
er . &c. quin capias E. ſi inuentus fuerit. &c. et eum ſaluo cuſtodi,De felon̄ ita quod habeas corpus eius coram A. B. et ſociis ſuis. &c. vt s. apud w. tali die proximo futuro, ad reſpondendū nobis de diuerſis feloniis, vnde indictatus eſt. Preci. etiam tibi. quod non omitt
er &c. quin diligenter inquiras, que bona et catalla predicta E. habet in ballina tua, et ea in manus nr̄as ſeiſcire fac, vx vlterius fieri poſſit, prout de iure rt ſecundum legem et conſuetud regni nr̄i Anglie fuerit faciend. Et habeas ibi tūc hoc preceptum. Teſte A B. Anno. regni noſtri viceſimo.

Intratio de alias.¶ Prec fuit vic. M. quod non omitt
er . &c. quin caperet. &c. et ſi. &c. et eum ſaluc cuſtodi, ita ꝙ
haberet corpus eius hic ad hunc diem, ad reſpondendū domino regi de diuerſis felon̄,Cap̄ de felonia. vn •• indictatus eſt, et ipſe non venit. Ideo preceptum eſt vic. ſicut al, quod non omitt
er . &c. quin cap̄. &c. et eum ſaluo. &c. ita quod habeat corpus eius coram A B. et ſociis ſuic. &c. apud. W. tali die proximo futuro, ad reſpondendum domino regi de diuerſis feloniis, vnde indictatus eſt Et quod idē diligenter inquirat, q̄ bona et catalla. &c. Et in manus domini. &c. vt vlterius. &c. vt ſupra.

¶ Preceptum eſt vic. M. ſicut alias p̄ceptum fuit,Alias cap̄ de felonia ꝙ non omitt
er &c quin capiat E. ſi inuentus fuerit in balliua ſua, & eū. &c. Ita ꝙ habea • corpus eius coram A B et ſociis ſuis. &c. apud W. tali die proximo futura, ad reſpondendum dn̄o regide diuerſis felon̄, vnde indictatus eſt, Pt
er eſt etiam v • c. ꝙ non omitt
er . &c. quin dilige •
ter inquirat, que bona et catalla predictus E. habet in balliua ſua, et ea in manus dn̄i regis ſeiſire fac. et inde ad diem et locum predictum, domino regi reſpondendi, vt vlterius in de ꝓ domino regi fieri poſſit, prout de iure & ſecund 〈◊〉 legem et conſuetudinem regni ſui Anglie fuerit faciēdū. Et habeat ibi tunc hoc precepr̄. &c. Teſt. A B. apud W. tali die &c.

¶ Precept
er fuit vic M. ſicut alias. &c. ꝙ no • omitt
er . &c. quin capiat E. ſi. &c et eum ſaluo. &c. Ita quod habeat coryus eius hic ad hunc diē ad reſpondendū domino regi de quibuſdam 〈◊〉 lon̄,Intt
ur de exigi faciſu per felon̄ vnde indiciatus eſt. Et quod inquirat. &c. et vic. rer̄. &c. quod predictus E. non eſt inuentus. Etiam quod idem E. nulla habet bona, et
catalls in ballius ſua, que in manus domini regis ſeiſ • re poſſunt, Vel aliter vic. t
ur quod habet talia bona et catalla ad valenc̄. &c. quo remanent in manibus F. dn̄o Regi inde reſponſutum. Ideo prec. eſt vic. quod exigi fac. cum te comitat
er in com̄ quouſque, &c. vtlagetur, ſi non comparuerit. Et ſi comparuerit. &c. tunc eum captat et ſaluo. &c. ita quod habeat corpus eiꝰ coram A B. et ſociis ſuis Iu • liciariis Pacis &c. apud W. tali die, ad reſpondendū dn̄o regi &c. indictatus eſt Vnde vic retorn̄, ꝙ predictus E. non fuit inuentus in balliua ſua. &c.

¶ Henricus de • gratia, rex Anglie Francie, et Hibernie, fidei defenſor vic. M. ſalutem.Erigi facias. Precipimus tibi, quod erigi fac. E. de com̄ in comit
er quouſ
que ſecundum leg • m et conſuetudinem regni noſtri Anglie vtlagetur, ſi non comparuerit, ei ſi comparuerit, tunc eum capias, & ſaluo cuſtod facias, ita ꝙ habeas corpus cius coram A B et ſociis ſuis cuſtod pacis noſtei, ac iuſtic. noſtris. &c. apud W. tali die, ad reſponden dum nobis de quibuſdam feloniis, vnde indicta tus eſt Et vnde tu ipſe mandaſti. &c.

¶ Et nota quod ſi con • ingat prefat
er E. antequam vtlagarus fuerit, venire coram prefatis Iu • ticiar̄ et reddire ſe legi, ad ſtādū legi in hac parte, • une habeas breue de ſuper ſ • quod ſequitur in hec verba. &c.

Suꝑ ſ. ſuꝑerigi &c. de felon̄.¶ Henricus dei gratia, rex Anglia Francie et Hibernie, fidei deteuſor, vic. M. ſalutem. Quia E. venit in curia noſtra coram A B. et ſoctis ſuis cu • tod pacis noſtre ac Iuſtic. noſtric ab diuerſas felon̄ tranſgr̄ et alis malefact
er in com̄
predicto audi endi et terminand aſſignat apud W tali die, et ſe redidit priſone noſtre occaſion • quarundam feloniarum, vnde indictatus eſt, vt in eadem moretur, ſicut nobis conſtat. Vel aliter Quia E. inuenit nobis ſufficien tem manucaptionem eſſendi coram prefatis Iuſtic. apud W. tali die proximo futuro, and reſpondend nobis de quibuſdā feloniis, vnde indictum eſt: ided tibi prec̄, quod de vlterius exigendo prefatum E • d aliquem com̄ tuum ſen impriſonand ſiue ipſum ea occaſione aliqualiter moleſtand, omnino ſuper ſ. Et habeas ibi hoc breue Teſte A B. apud W. tali die. Anno regni noſtri. veſicimo.

¶ Henricus dei gracia. &c. Quia E. venit in cut
er noſtra coram A B. & ſociis ſuis,Su
que ſ. ſuper trn̄s. cuſtod pacis noſtri. &c. et inuenit ſuffic, manucaptor̄ eſſendi coram prefat

Et etiam ꝙ poſſunt capere omnes, qui non ſunt be • ona fame, vbi

Recogn̄ pro pace.¶ Memorandum ꝙ .x. die Iulii. Anno regni regis Henrici .vii. viſiſimo primo Wilhelmus G Iohannes D. et Iohaunes. T. venerunt coram me R S. vno Iuſtic. dicti domini regis ad pacem com̄ predicio conſeruand aſſign̄, et manuceperunt pro Iohanne. nuper de London̄ yoman, ꝙ ipſe perſonaliter comparebit coram me p̄fat R. vel ſociis meis Iuſtic. dn̄i regis ad proximam generalem ſeſſionem pacis apud C. in com̄ predico reuend. Et interim ꝙ ipſe geret pacem erga cunctum populum dicti dn̄i regis et precipue erga Robertum Crane, videlicet quilibet manucaptorum ſub pena. x. li. Et pred I D. manuc̄. ꝓ ſcipſo ſub pena .xx. li. &c. ¶ Memorand ꝙ .xx. die. Iulii. Anno regni regis Henrici .vii. viceſimo. Robertus C. de London̄ gentylman.Alia recogn̄ pro felonia. Edmundus Caryngton de eadem gentylman, Iohannes Baynearde de eadem gentylman, et Wilhelmus Codington de eadē yoman, venerunt coram nobis Roberto
S. wambi, & Richardo Parker, duobus Iuſticiaris dicti domini rēgis ad pacē in com̄ Eſſex conſeruand, aſſign̄, & manuceperunt pro R P de Londō gent
er , vem quilibet eorum corpꝰ pro corpore quod idem R. perſonaliter compatebit coram prefat
er Iuſtic. & ſocits ſuis ad ꝓilmam generalem Seſſionem pacis apud M. in com̄ predicto tenendū ad ſtand rect
er in curia, ſi quis verſus eum loqui voluerit de diuerſis feloniis et tranſgreſſ vnde idem R P. indictatus exiſtit (vt dicitur) et ad reſpondendum dicto domino regi de iſdem, prout debet. &c.

• a .xx. li. quod ipſe ſecuritatem pacis bene geret erga cunctum populum noſtrum, et precipue erga Iohannem Brown̄ Iun̄, ita ꝙ ipſe dampnum vel malum aliquod prefat
er I B. ſiue alicui de populo noſtro de corporibus ſuis, aut mutilatione membrorum ſuorum, necuou de incendio domorum ſuarum non fac. nec fieri procurabit quouiſmodo, et ad comparendū coram
Iuſticiaris noſtris prediciis ad proximam ſeſſidnem pacis apud C. tenend, ideo vobis et cuilibet veſtrum precipimus et mandamus, ꝙ de captione, ſiue arreſtat
ur corporis predicti Iohannis P. ꝓ huiuſmodi ſecuritate mueniendū ſuperſediatis omnino. Et ſi ipſum Iohannem Parker ea accaſione et non alia ceperitis, ſiue vnus veſtrum ceperit, ſiue impriſonaueritis ſeu vnus veſtrū ceꝑit, ſiue impriſonauer̄ tunc eum ab hōi priſona ſine dilatione deliberari fac. ſeu vnus veſtrum deliberari faciat. Teſte prefat
er R S. apud M. tali die. Anna regni nr̄i. xxi.
¶ Relaxacio ſecuritatis pacis.

☞ R G. de D. in com̄ E. xi. die Iulii. Anno. regni regis. H. vii. rvii. venit coram me A S. Vno Iuſtie. &c. et gratis remiſit et relarauit ſecuritatem pacis ꝑ ipſū verſus T W. peti
ur , &c

div.head:
¶ Indict
er de alta proditione.
div.p:
INquiratur pro dūo rege, Capi. i. Si Recūs M nuper de S. in com̄ K. ac ali • falſi proditores • t inimici metuediſſ. ac chriſtianiſſimi principis E. regis Anglie .iiii. poſt conqueſtum Anglie ignot
er die & An. &c. apud ſaint Elyns in inſals Victa, in Comitatu Southhamt
er inſimul congragauerunt tunc et ibidem vi et acmis, vibelicet gladiis. &c. Inſurrererunt quo
